content:
Posted: January 21
												So, I know that this isn't a city builder but a city ruler blablabla. However, the gameplay is incredibly shallow in most aspects. The concept is amazing and I think the devs wasted some potential with this game. The main issues I have with the game are, as I said, shallow city sim related gameplay you might be used to get from other games - which in itself wouldn't be a major deal if other aspects of the game would be more interesting. However, there is no real roleplaying aspect other than the occasional trait points you get (or lose), flavour text for characters and houses.Then there is the "political" side of the game, which is pretty disappointing. You basically have a bunch of political parties that shift in power. Wanna pass a law and parties that support it are in the minority? No problem, just tell the leader of an opposing party that you'll ruin his career or straight out threaten to murder him and there you go, vote passed. Zone out a disctrict or build a police station? Threaten people. Increase taxes, funding for something, strenghten LGBT rights from horrible to kinda horrible or get ♥♥♥♥ing elected? DO THE EXACT SAME ♥♥♥♥ING THING! Why is there no campaigning for elections? No political intrigues, managing your own party or whatever else politics could have been implemented in this game?A price tag of ~20 bucks would be acceptable for this game. I'd say factoring in the current price of €45 for me, I'd give it a 4/10. Disregarding price, a 6/10.

number of helpful: 15 of 26 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3
												Urban empire is a very niche game, despite of its marketing and initial price tag that suggested a quasi-AAA title. It decides to go against the critically acclaimed Cities Skylines, and it endorses Tropico's political system more than ever before. Why am I endorsing the game? They are going in a certain direction that games don't usually go - and as far as I am concerned, I like it because it's a difficult road and not many players nowadays enjoy the city-building + politics combo. Big time. And I think innovations need to be endorsed, promoted and helped.That's Calypso for you. They make awesome niche games focused on the city building+politics combo that just get better - first Tropico, now Urban Empire. It's just all about time - they decided to stop being lazy, go on the politics road and keep it up.If you dont like to read, then watch me ramble for 20 minutes or so: 


YouTube™ Video: Urban Empire is well worth the buy! 

			Views: 40		

			In this video, I explain why I really liked Urban Empire, and why is it worth to buy it.		

Lets take a look at the good.GOOD:1. The politics system really helps the game. It wrenches the control out of the player's hands, and while others would complain, I find it the best positive thing in the game. This is MFing real life. Political parties have their own views, their own agendas, their own principles, and try as you might, a mayor can only do so much. Ok, short of being the Green Arrow, I guess...2. They have chosen the perfect setting - the second half of the 19th century, when things really started kicking into high gear for the humanity as we know it - all over the world. I am very happy they did it.3. The different maps provide different challenges, and the player needs to plan for that. I like it.4. The replayability is good in my book. I have played 2 maps with 2 different families and it felt like a different game. Was it just me carrying over my experience of the first game? I don't think so. While the setting is relatively similar, playing to the strengths of your family is a big deal and enforces a number of different playstyles. And speaking about playstyles...5. Playstyles differ, and work. So far in my games, I managed to create a workers' paradise, where the lower class pays almost nothing in taxes, and in my other game I managed to create a technocratic society where everyone contributed and went tech crazy. I can see so much potential for roleplay here. I love it. I could say more about the system, but the female part of the humankind will hate me, and I'd rather not, because I am very much into women, as they represent the better part of our society!6. Last, but not least, the city does indeed change because of your actions, which is really nice to see. Whether it will be the buildings, the street light, hell, even the amount of people walking the streets, it's still a very welcome change from a player's perspective.Good, good, good. But there is bad, and it's a lot. 1. The game is easy. You will most likely be able to win it in the first go, especially if you already have some experience with city builders and how they work2. Prestige, while being an awesome thing, is used improperly in my opinion. It needs to be family/mayor based, and not accumulated throughout the entire game. Or at least make it so that you can't use it to overrule mayor elections - because no matter how bad you lose, you can still use prestige to stay in power. While the cost to stay in power does rise, if you are remotely good at this type of game you will win, and still sit on a very hefty amount of prestige. And about that...3. I just wish that Calypso will endorse the fact that gamers do like challenge. So far their city/politics games have been extremely gamer-friendly. It's like playing XCOM, losing the mission, getting everyone killed, but have a itty bitty little button in the corner of the screen that says "Spend 10 Supply to win" and by a snap of Q's fingers everyone is alive and all's good. Welp...4. Invalid district shape shouldn't have been considered as a game option, and district shapes should have been completely overhauled - especially in the types of maps the developers created. All those corners do not help the district building, people, especially in the way you made it. Inexperienced people will sometimes forfeit a huge chunk of the playing area just because of your "regulations". Thanks, but no thanks.5. Being a niche game, it promises more that people expect. I don't like it, as it misrepresents many, many things. The devs made it sound like it's Cities Skylines with a political system - which is something everyone will buy, and bite into - and be bitterly disappointed.6. Again, last but not least, there are bugs. I, myself posted a screenie in which an event cause the game to bug and got me like 7 million debt in a tick, even though I was easily in the positive amounts of cash influx - this immediately affected my game, as it reduced my ability to play the way that I wanted, and forced me to cheat (meaning raise a ton of taxes, and the parliament agreed easily, which also helped me later on) - which is a bad thing. Of course, don't get me started on the frame rate drops... Thank God I am a gamer since 1998, which mens I don't really pay attention to that, and it doesn't bother me much - but I know for a fact that it ticks a ton more people to no end.Time to interject before the conclusion...You might have noticed that I didn't talk about the graphics, the sound, etc. They are ok and do the game justice. What I am trying to say with this review, is that, even by endorsing this game, Calypso need to step up their game and understand where the industry is at. It's about time they introduced multiple difficulties in an appropriate, and dare I say MEANINGFUL fashion. It's time to get out of their shell and do the proper thing. I know for a fact that they have the capability to do so, as they have proven in with the tropico series and this very game, Urban Empire - they just need to do it in their next game, or they will always be the niche dev that makes good games for specific audiences, but never great games.Conclusion:I am endorsing the game because I am having great fun with it, and because I believe that the developers have what it takes to step up their game and make the next cities skylines with a politics system. It may happen or not - but it is hard for me not to get by the fact that I am having lots of fun playing Urban Empire, and that I find each family to pose different challenges - and as some of you might know, I judge my games by game hours vs value - and to me, this one sure as hell merits it. Each play-through lasts about 8 hours, and with 4 families, varying political systems, and roleplaying to boot, it easily overgrows its money value. Want to make an city where women do nothing else but give birth to kids to prolong lineages? You can! (and did you just see me contradict myself?! I bet you did, as far as positive 5 is concerned...) Want to make the ultimate balanced society? You can! Want to be the best modern society? You sure as hell can! I absolutely love the amount of options this game gives me, and for that - I thank it! Do you? That's a question you need to answer for yourself.

content:
Posted: January 20
												I wish I could recommend this game, but I don't see any way to get to that point with what we currently have to play.  There's zero strategy involved, it's essentially impossible to lose.  As long as you do bulk upgrades of districts when they go up for vote, you'll always have plenty of goodwill.  As long as you raise taxes regularly, you'll never be short of money.  No matter how unhappy your people are, it never actually reflects in the game itself.  It took me an hour on speed 4 to get to age 3, and the only differences were slightly different building names that essentially do the same thing as prior buildings.  Once you factor in the increasing demand from successive ages the new buildings do almost literally the exact same thing, since their higher bonuses are offset completely.  If you had some idea what most actions would do, it would help considerably.  Instead you normally have no idea what any option will do, although occasionally you'll have a tooltip for one or all of the options, although this is rare.  It's just currently not fun at all, and I deeply regret my pre purchase.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21
												The good: the game has a brilliant idea. You have either governance games (Paradox) or city builders, but this one marries the two ideas into a hands-on governance game. Few games such as this exist (best one being probably Tropico 4). I think this goes even beyond Tropico in terms of depth, with the existence of formal votes and political parties, so kuddos to the creators for thinking about such an interesting concept.The bad: well, the game gets repetitive very fast, as the political mechanics do the same thing over and over again. There is no sandbox mode per se at this stage, and the optimization is poor. Without the graphics or the underlying mechanics being something to go "wow" about, the game runs slowly and camera controls are wonky. Tropico 5 runs faster and has even better graphics, and larger maps.. Lastly, the interface is horrendous, non-intuitive and difficult to master. Fonts are small, and many players (myself included) had trouble saving the game (due to the insistence on a new save name) or in-game actions due to poor instructions. Sadly, on top of a fairly high cost (at €45 I expect this game not to become a DLC rally point), the poor features make me go for "no" for this game, and I intend to request a refund.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21
												Not the game they describe. This is not a Mayoral sim; it is a very shallow city builder with a political menu thrown in. Yes you can change taxes, edicts, which party is the most of in power, etc. However the only way to do this is through goodwill, no bribes, no actual threats, no assasinations, no political kidnapping (which was still very common in the 1800's), very poor blackmail system, etc. Everything's just horribly over simplified on the surface. You dig deeper and you find out the goodwill system is the absolute CORE of your political career. So an Imperial aggressive play style lands you in hot water fast. Imperials  want the same laws (such as freaking labor unions?!?!?!?!?) as the populists. Why? Because it gives a bonus to the people of the city if you pass it. How about workers safety? Sounds expensive to implement FDA and OSHA regulations right? Nope, implementing it increases sales. What the ever living ****! I mean I'd get more workers would want to work but higher safety should makes your profits go down not up. These devs  put absolutely no effort into a "Real" political system. Then you come into the horrible part, not only is the political system simple, it's also geared to the NPC. Let me explain, let's say an Imperial opposes bills that are trying to be passed by a Populist. You will lose council members (consistent votes) to that party because the people of the city prefer the party that benefits them most. So I allowed them to take power while using large amounts of good will to control their votes and the votes of the other parties. I ended up 6 districts in producing a very consistent 40-60k a month at 13/13 taxes. Then the Populists decide let's tax the people less (6%) and commercial and industrial businesses more (17%). 4 districts went bankrupt within 1.5 years, as I was completely unable to do anything in the council because I had almost no party members and no support. I'll also add that I was playing the way the campaign TELLS you to play. Whether they intentionally run you into the ground or not I'm not sure. Can't afford lights and roads or any institutions as there's a constant fluctuation in income such as making 170k a year then going -31k from everything going bankrupt with no explanation what from.All I can say is this game failed, and it failed hard. The entire system feels unbalanced, unpolished, unrewarding, and just simply put, not fun at all. Run, run far away. Go spend $5 on The Guild 2: Renaissance and you'll see a simple political system that still has bugs and troubles yet still vastly out performs Urban Empire. This is in no way worth $40, maybe $15 if they fixed...well everything.. But be prepared to wait 2 years.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20
												The game brings aspects of politically-driven and city-building games that come together to create a unique experience. Utilizing a district zoning method with other controls (such as adjusting the density of the district to be sparse or tight-knit, or changing the amount of lots dedicated to residential, commercial, etc.), you are able to plot out the literal squares of your city. However, the thing that caught most people off guard is that you don't manually place buildings except for municipal services (like schoolhouses, clinics, or fire stations). Most of the changes that impact the city and change the outlook of things take place in the senate where you propose tax hikes/cuts, adjust funding, and issue edicts for approval. Depending on the relationship between the mayor (player) and present political factions and their spot on the political compass, they will ultimately decide if you are able to carry out your plans. The game is mostly a balancing act where you try to weigh it to your side. From time to time, the game will pose events that impact your contstituents and need your input, like if you support or want to abolish child lavor, support alcohol liscenses, or if you should enstate anti-pollution laws.I for one enjoyed what the game had to offer, and would recommend this game to any individual who wants a game to simulate real political functions and to also revel in making personal decisions about the citizens you reside over.If I had any critques about the game, I'd say that a neater user interface would be better, and to make alerts to the player more visble and last longer. Secondly, have the tutorial go more in=depth about companies and how to make revenue.

												So far, I really like this game. I've now gone into Era 3 with 3 of the 4 families, played on each of the maps, and I'd definitely say that there is a good base for replayability. Depending on what studios you're used to (Paradox, anyone?) you may already be used to that sort of thing and are willing to be patient.I do agree though, $40 seems a bit steep at the moment. Still, I usually can't wait very long to try out new games in the genre, and I ultimately thought it was worth it.

												Disappointing, the politicking is ostensibly designed to provide some challenge but all the purpose it seems to serve is to slow you down (since you can only have one vote up at a time for rezoning/doing new districts/etc), but it doesn't. If you have money your votes will pretty much always pass. If your budget is messed up you can always pass a tax increase, most of the decisions presented to you are meaningless, and traffic, probably the biggest issue in almost any city builder is just not a concern because you don't lay your own roads. Votes are extremely predictable because even with the thinnest of margins visible the neutrals will pretty much always split 50/50.Might be a little fun but definitely not worth it in its current state. Knowing Kalypso the game will probably never be an actual challenge so I wouldn't hold out if you're looking for that.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4
												I really want to like this game but the way it currently plays is both frustrating and obfuscated. It really is a city builder game with a very awkward "Do not pass go" Council screen passing for the difference between Builder and Ruler. Ultimately it starts getting in the way. It needs to be streamlined to be less offensive to the continuing gameplay.Then there's the mechanics of how and why your city grows or doesn't grow. Very few of the factors are fully explained to the point where you can comprehend them and utilise or react to them properly. A very slight change to your city perhaps even a change to just the city's potential and not even to it's physical nature (e.g. upgrade a district to potentially have higher density buildings) and suddenly everyone might move out sending you into a debt spiral you can never recover from.Then there are story-driven decisions you have to make (will you the Major endorse X or Y etc). Some of them reveal their consequences in terms of modifications to various stats and some of them don't. There appears to be no rhyme or reason for the latter.The game is also pretty poor on the graphical front. Ignore the lovely close-ups in the trailers. You'll never be looking at your city like that and even if you do take a moment to zoom in it really isn't impressive in the flesh. As your city grows so does your frame-rate slow. Even on a massively overclocked i7 and watercooled 1080GTX it tanks completely as the city gets larger. Eventually it crashes raising the ghost of a possible memory leak.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22
												I pre-purchased this game with a Steam gift card I received. I pretty much have all the games I want to play on Steam already so I figured I would try this out. I watched a few pre-release game plays and the game seemed okay.The game touts itself as a mix of politics and "city-management". It lacks very much of any deviation from what the developers 'intended' the player to go through. It is very mechanical in the way the player just 'pulls levers' and waits to see what happens. The order in which you make decisions for research feels like it makes little difference to the direction of your city. It lacks flavor as the player can only choose a few families to play, three maps without much character themselves, and a lack of politic actions. The political action is to 'make appeals' to the different parties and gets old once you do it 100+ times.This game could've been so much more (perhaps a mix between Cities Skylines and Crusader Kings?) but it lacks flavor and became monotonous very quickly. Not worth the price tag, even at the 10 or 20% off I bought it at. It reeks of a classic Kalypso game: second tier.EDIT:Another small thing that annoyed me was the lack of ability to zoom out further. I felt constrained to look always be looking at a small section of the map. The map up-close wasn't even that 'detailed' so I'm not sure why the emphasis was to be close. It's just something small that I bet could be quickly patched in to allow the player to zoom out further.

content:
Posted: January 22
												Mechanically the game is fairly shallow. The politics are not terribly engaging or intuative, a lot of data seems to exist within the game but many tooltips are missing or otherwise unavailable, leaving a lot of the game feeling arbitrary.With only three maps for the core game it feels thin. They aren't very large maps, either. And while it may boast 1000~ dynamic events, most of them appear to be very shallow or poorly implimented, and don't seem to have long term effects other than changing one or two stats in a district.Visually it's not appealing, either, and while that is not what I nor anyone else should necessarily be looking for in a managment/strategy game, the layouts of the roads interfere a lot with how structures are placed and spawn in and create very unappealing environments.In and of its self, the game seems good, but many bugs and poorly implimented aspects of the game add up, and at the asking price of this game, it just isn't worth the price in its current state. It feels as though it is a mobile game.edit: While it is true that I only played on and a half hours of the game, I've looked at a substantial stretch of content on the game on youtube before proceeding, which confirmed my suspicions about the game going forward. The game could certainly have used a longer development cycle, I understand that the money could have been needed to finish development and pay people, but there needs to be more communication with the community in a more central place on the situation of the game if that is the case, or otherwise.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21
												Interesting premise, but poorly executed and certainly not worth £35.For anyone looking for their next city-building fix, this isn't it. It's very much more of a political simulator in the vein of Democracy or Fate of the World. However, I'm not sure that works entirely well with the city building aspects as they don't give you the flexibility to make the kind of decisions you'd like to make. For example, you build (or rather, seek permission to build) service buildings like schools and clinics which have an effective radius. But you can't choose specifically which blocks are residential, commercial etc, only the proportion spread within a neighbourhead, which means you end up placing services in less than optimal positions.The evolution of the city through the ages is a nice touch, as it the way the politics changes with the times. Unfortunately, it basically plays out exactly the same way with each playthrough, and other than a few shorter, limited, scenarios you ultimately have to play the same Swarelia story. I guess this will be supported with future DLC but at £35 already this is a bit of a rip-off, especially without a simple sandbox mode.The game also has a few bugs; and the economic model doesn't entirely make much sense. You'll be spending a lot of time just waiting for things to happen...Overall, if you can get this for £10 in a sale, it's worth a playthrough as the game is definitely original, but there's nowhere near enough here to justify a full price title.

content:
Posted: January 22
												I will start by saying that I am having a lot of fun with this game. I love the concept, but the execution is a little... off.Most of the reasons for this have already been stated. The interface should be improved dramatically, it takes too many clicks and submenus to do things that I should just be able to do with one click. I have experienced my fair share of graphical bugs that have caused me to restart the game. The tooltips are not as helpful as they should be in explaining the effects of what's going on. For instance, it will say +1 Change in a certain area. Sounds good, but exactly what change was made? It just says change. That's not helpful at all. I also believe certain things are overpriced, and what exactly does upgrading your infrastructure even do? I've been using dirt roads forever with no problems. What is my incentive to spend all this cash on upgrading then? Speaking of overpriced, $39.99 is a bit much to charge for a game that should be considered early-access at this point. I feel like I am test running a beta version. $29.99 or even $34.99 would be more acceptable to me, and give me more realistic expectations for the game. As it stands, I cannot reccommend the game, however, in a few months when all the bugs are worked out and the interface is improved, I will absolutely recommend it. TL;DR Great concept, poor execution.

content:
Posted: January 21
												A Refrishing Swim in a Shallow PondPros:+ Very few titles in the genre+ What it does, mayoral simulator, it does well+ Peaceful, layed back gameplay+ Runs well and looks as good as it needs to beCons:- Not a lot going on, there are times where you're just waiting for the time to tick by.- The game's politics definitely tend to lean one way moreso than the other- Difficult to tell what choices makes what changesNeutral:o Shallow gameplay. You make choices and hope you have enough clout to sway votes to your side. That's pretty much it in a nutshell.o There definitely seems to be an optimal way to go about advancing your city and districts.It's a difficult genre to make a game for as the demand is quite low. Personally I love these types of games and there are very few additions every year that are worth checking out. The problem here is that to appeal to a wider audience they tap into city building and planning elements that are just too shallow for those looking for a city builder. If you know what you're getting into before buying, it should scatch that proverbial mayoral itch.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20
												TL;DR This game is a indirect city management game with politics that takes some time to figure out and is deceptively complex.This is a fairly unique management simulation.You are a mayor who is one of several stereotypical dynasties who has been granted control of a city.You take no direct hand in building it but must manage the city indirectly though successful political maneuvering of the council.The game has a very familiar city-builder-esque cycle:1. Choose and Object to build2. Wait for budget to be positive enough to sustain it.rinse, repeatIt adds a few other things to the cycle:Petition the council for funding of your project or fund it yourself.Intorduce laws and get them passed.In between all this you must regularly make decisions on various events both random and othewise presented to you. These events can have bigger consequences than they first appear.Early on in this game; I felt like all the options they give you in manageing the political parties were just different shades of the same flavor but the political system is actually much more subtely complex than I thought.Another thing that ended up being more interesting than it first appeared is the economy.If you enjoy games like Crusader Kings 2, Victoria 2 (really any paradox grand strategy or grand strategy games in general) You will probably like this game. If you want an outlet for your creative outbursts this will probably end up frustrating and boring you.

number of helpful: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20
												City builder with the political aspects of games like Democracy 3, and a Penultimo cameo.I rather enjoy it, because with the political aspect, you need to pick and choose your battles. Always strongarming the council into getting your way WILL backfire on you.Build new districts when the economy is booming, increase taxes when it's in the red and always keep at least 10X the city's income in the treasury for cases where the economy turns around.The council is remarkably reasonable as long as you don't strong arm them. They will go against their own political compass if the economy is threatened or if it's booming and play to the approval of the public. If your city has high education, even the conservatives are likely to vote yes on progressive matters to avoid loosing approval.And if you have trouble getting something trough the council, like expanding infastructure in a district? Do it in steps as it's much easier to get trough.However if you try to play it like any other city builder and constantly strongarm even your political enemies.. you're going to have a bad time. So don't do it. Go with the political flow and try to focus on a healthy economy with your own ideals for the city being secondary.Doing as described above, I was able to expand the city into 6-7 districts before the first era was over and with a few 100k in income, which I managed to expand into over a million by the third era. As a result I only ever had to persuade or strongarm the council in 1 or 2 matters so far, and where the vote didn't go my way or I needed to get it trough despite the council makign it impossible, I just overturned it instead of trying to strongarm every party and move them into negative approval as i seemed to take a much lower hit from overturning the vote and the good will bounces much faster back from a 1-2 hit accross the board than from a 5-8 hit on a few parties.Also if you have trouble starting off and expanding, then start out by raising taxes 3-4% and as soon as you're in the positive after building the first district, zone another before you start adding services. It'll give you a bigger starting population & industry which will help keep your economy strong and make it much easier to continue expanding after adding services.

If you know what you're getting into before buying, it should scatch that proverbial mayoral itch.

number of helpful: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21
												TL;DR Dont waste your money hoping that they fix it eventually or have the balls to sell you a DLC that implements what should have been in the core gameThis game is great in concept, and very very poor in implementation. I have played to completion a few times, and can say this:1)	LLAAAAAGGGGGG - Regardless of others saying "it plays fine", if you are a successful mayor and get 10-15k population by around Era 3, the game will CRAWL. I have SSDs, 32GB RAM, and a 6 core CPU with HT. And it is literally single FPS by the time you hit Era 5. There is no way they didnt notice this in development, and yet they threw it out there anyways. Unacceptable.2)	This appears to be based on some designers idea of how politics work. Choices you make may or may not do what you think they do, and there is no information denoting what the overall effect might be. I don’t need the game to let me min/max, but I would like to at least understand who supports various initiatives, and what they are likely to vote for. It feels like there is some formula, but it is very unclear what that is. This makes every decision very frustrating.3)	When information is presented, it is done in an awkward and confusing manner. For example there are lots of stats about each district available, but none of them cover “what does this district need?” or “How do I address problem X?” So even when there is info available, it is still frustrating just trying to make sense of it.4)	The engine designer must have done the UI also because the way things like bonuses are presented is horrible. “Sales Bonus! Demand -10%!”. Even if the engine calculated a bonus as -10% for something, why in the world would you present it like that. Its just backwards.5)	Citizen desires, which they call The Wheel of Life are presented as offsets to the current era target. So you have a hard time understanding how much better you need to make things. They should just show it as “11/15” instead of “-4”. Even then, once you learn to understand what it means, how to solve that issue is unclear.6)	Nothing has any consequence. It doesnt matter what youve done or how you treat the parties. Vote for the most liberal policy available, have money in the bank and the coucil will love you.7)	Citizens dont care if its the modern era and they have no utilities and dirt roads. It makes no difference whatsoever. You can buy off the vote and people still drive around on dirt roads. If the game lets you see details, you could see people checking stuff out on their ipads while walking along next to the cow droppings. Luckily the game doesnt let you zoom in ( or out ) enough to notice.As I said, this game could be really good and after playing it a few times I can see where they were going with it. But the developer just did a very bad job of putting it into action in a way that makes sense to most people. Sure you can learn how to read their numbers, but I should have to work at learning the strategy, NOT at figuring out how to read their statistics. This is a $10 game with more polish than you would expect from that price range and a big publisher. For $40 its early access at BEST, and honestly, Im very skeptical of how deep the game would be even if it didnt have the litany of bugs. There are literally mobile games with more complexity, and better UIs!

content:
Posted: January 27
												It was fun, but definitely not worth it. There are so many limitations, it's hard to know where to start.I find working with the city council to be fun, interesting, and definitely a high point in the game. Though, they could use a bit of tweaking since after awhile, they'll agree to any tax hike.The worse part of the game is the actual gameplay - you can't do a whole lot except build more districts and upgrade them one at a time. The economy also needs some serious tweaking since building districts is the only way to get more money. And don't even think about offering infrastructure for your people or you'll run out of money.I think this game could be a lot better if a few additional dynamics were added:1. Talking to concern citizens who would like your to grant permits, endorse their business, or to mingle with them (parties, balls, etc)2. Some ability to deal with the press would be a nice change of pace. How your interactions impacts your relations with the city council3. More district control - would make this a way better game. Instead, all I can determine is density and zoning4. Interactions with the outside world - The Emperor requests you to take in refugees? Crime issue? Things that an actual mayor has to deal with?In any case. The game is a great concept - but it's too limited, too plain, and just not worth the money. Maybe wait for it to go on sale or something.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21
												Ok, got enough hours in now to comment. Actually feels like I've seen it all already. I really like management games, just like I like games involving means of manipulation or sneaky means to achieve your goal. The prospect of having to influence the council to get my will really appealed to me. Sadly I have that the way it is executed in this game isn't for me. I will actually start with the Cons on this one:Cons- The praised 1000 events are boring with very minor (if at all impact). It's just a popup, you choose an option and get a mostly useless bonus or harmless malus. I had hoped for some event chains, something requiring action and something refreshing now and then. Nothing. - Economy often makes no sense whatsoever. The income drops and increases A LOT rather randomly and you don't even get a hint of why. The statistic tab is abismal. Most stuff you can't really read out of it.- The family choice is bland and rather meaningless. I usually approve roleplay elements like this but this is VERY basic and not fun.- I really hoped for more of an impact of the world's events on the town. There is (close to) nothing there. That makes absolutely no sense.- There really isn't much point in optimisation. At times the most profitable districts are the basic ones without any costly upgrades.- Based on my observations there seems to be only one real way to be financially successful (not spoiling it). All attempts to use other playstyles that based on the data given (demands for residents, commercy, industry) would have made way more sense ended horribly bad.- I see close to no replay value. The events don't offer any. Pros:- The approach for science is nice and refreshing.- Living through the changes in history e.g. the rights of women, the privileges initially reserved to few yet opened up over time is quite fun.

												This game doesn't feel complete at all. Tutorial is sketchy and superficial , and doesnt explain all the game mechanics to run the city properly. The political side of things is ridiculous. Everything runs on goodwill and prestige , which the tutorial conveniently left out on how to obtain it.The city building side fared better , click to add options to district and buildings.  However ,  what the tutorial neglected to teach was how to generate more money for the city which usually leaves players struggling to build a city they like.  In this aspect , sims like Tropico feels easier to understand. Another thing i hated was how boring it became as the the game went on. Things got repetitive fairly quickly. Research new tech , wait forever just to have the money to implement 1 of the perks of the new tech in a part of your city , fight the various political factions to pass through the agreement to build that single building or implement that new tech , which is fairly ridiculous to me. This game doesn't feel like it has a end game objective. Sure, there are victory conditions listed in the logbook , be it for campaign mode or scenario mode , but the campaign mode's background story is just that , a background distraction. There is no story or plot whatsoever to immerse in . I wouldn't recommend this game at all , unless you have hours to burn and you have really absolutely nothing else to play.

												This game showed a lot of promise, and still could be great, however, right now, its not. There are plenty of problems, inaccuracies, and drawbacks, but ultimately, what sinks this game is taxes. Income is seemingly random, shoots up and down massively month to month, and taxes need to constantly be raised just to keep your head above water. Its not fun to vote on taxes every 5 minutes,  by 1920 I had reached the ludicrously high tax rate of 95%, the maximum, and it still wasn't enough for basic level one services. I wish the devs all the best, and hope this game can be fixed, but right now I regret spending 40 dollars for 4 hours a gameplay before I decided it was time to move on.

I was told to build a district and denied.  I don't know why people like one thing v. another. Are they getting sick and do we really need more clinics?  Plus 2 up on top for health doesn't really do it for me.I would like to be able to have more insight on the politics.  Why do we have to vote on everything?  What do the people want more in order to grow?  The demand bars also aren't doing it.Updates need to happen and then I'll update my status.  Look at your reviews guys and see that we need a change - bit time.  You have a great concept for a game - this can be a winner, but fix what needs to be fixed.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23
												tl;dr it plays like a really basic city builder that delays construction when you've gotten into the swing of things. This should be early access at best, it needs loads of refining to be anywhere near what they have been showcasing.It's 1960, my people are quite happy with my governing of the city, there's no water lines, sewage pipes or electric anywhere within the city. Despite this the Television business is booming, not sure how my people intend to watch the TV's, but I can't judge them.The roads are still the same old dirt roads from the 1800's everyone is happy to drive around their cars on this with minimal traffic problems.The communist party is quite happy for me to raise tax on the working class and lower it for the elite.The game boasts having an indepth political system where you need to battle with different parties to make changes, but there's no point at all in picking favourites to buddy up with as all relations with these parties will reset back to 0 after a couple of years. So you can generally treat them how you want.City expansion only becomes a problem if you have both a low income and low funds in the account, as then all parties will try to block all decisions you make. However if you're sitting there with a few hundred k in the bank, they will generally green light everything you want to do, like build an electrical power plant purely to export the power it creates.The parties as well are not really sticking to what you think they would, you will quite often see the conservatives pushing for social equality with the progressive sides trying to block these movements, and as mentioned before, communists liking to tax the working class high.The people in your city are quite happy to live with no water, electric or gas supplies. You can add these services to districts, but you get no return for doing so, people won't pay extra for them, so you're just throwing money away. They do claim to "boost companies" but again, increasing the sales of companies in your city doesn't actually do anything for your own income.The rpg story elements hardly do anything for the game, you can choose one of 4 families with different back stories and ideas towards governing. All switching between these really does it decide which events you're going to get, and they will be the same ones each time at the exact same time, you get a few outside of this, like parties wanting to make you honourary members etc. but they're mostly meaningless. Your character has traits, cruel, soft, opitmist etc. again, mostly meaningless. You might get the odd event pop up with a response option blocked due to lack of x trait, but refering back, your traits and what you say on these windows rarely matters.Until elections come around, you don't need to make your citizens happy at all. No chance of an uprising due to lack of healthcare, policing, leisure or anything at all. You can quite happily ignore all the demands of your citizens until the ability to vote comes along, and you can even try to prevent that for an extended time.Small aesthetic thing that bothers me. Why can I see loads of cars driving around my city when I've not even researched them yet. Also why do all the houses and shops have lights on at night if there's absoloutely no electrical grids in the city.The game had some great ideas with the whole political thing, you can even blackmail parties, but they just don't mean anything towards running the city. You can spend the entire game never having to speak to any of them apart from suggesting changes to the city and waiting for them to agree on it.And the fact that you can have a city with 0 utilities and everyone is ok with that bewilders me, but then you can't afford to give them to the entire city anyway.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21
												First off, I am a HUGE fan of the Tropico series, so I may be a bit biased. That said, this is easily one of the most addictive games that I've played in a LONG time.You really have to give it a chance, though. The first half-dozen playthroughs, it can feel like it is just unbelievably hard. Then I realized that I didn't need to wait for the game to tell me to add another district. Once your first district fills up, make sure your cashflow is positive, and build another district. That will set you back in the short-term, but then you'll get into a rhythm of building new districts, adding services, waiting until they fill up with industry/commercial buildings - and then rinse, and repeat.The real meat comes in the way that you choose to develop the tech, and add services or stockpile wealth. Will you try to up your salary early, so that you can bypass votes and build freely? Will you let the council do what they will, and save your points for a rainy day?I did, and that's where I really started having fun with it. It sort of feels like you're "winning" if your city has electricity before the 1800's are out. I unlocked contraception and womens' right to choose around 1860 in one game, and it felt like I had created a cultural Mecca out of nothing.Of course, I blew it in the next era by adding services more quickly than I was sourcing revenue or adding new districts, and had to start over. But now, I enjoy every restart, because I have new ideas for how to develop my city. This time, electric early and straight to assembly line. Oh, but I added electric lights in my first district too early, and now we're broke? And I spent all of my political capital getting here, and two of the parties are♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥at me?Time for a fresh start!TL;DL : Released today (yesterday?). Haven't slept, brain hurts. 10/10, Would disturb sleep patterns, again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28
												In a nutshell, while I did enjoy this game enough to give it a positive, it certainly deserves the MIXED reaction.At a glance, Urban Empire is a city builder, but is billed a "city ruler". This is kind of true in some ways, but the actual mechanics behind the political side are very, very shallow. The general premise of the game is that you have to manage a town across 200 years, from the Industrial Revolution to modern times, while juggling the personal lives of your family thorugh decision-based events that don't really affect the game much, but add some flavour.The appeal in the game is, as with many city builders, figuring out how to do it right. There's satisfaction in getting a good cashflow, seeing happiness go up and optimising your districts. There's enough there to keep you hooked if you know the basics of not crashing your economy.The problem is that the game has VERY POOR player feedback. It doesn't really set you in the right direction - in fact, the in-game tutorial tips set you up to fail right away. There is a sore lack of tooltips, and many icons simply don't make sense at a glance. The exact relationship between residential, commercial and industrial demand is not made clear to the player. The underlying mechanics do seem solid, but they're not presented in a meaningful way to the player. As a result, it's very easy to make a poor decision and put yourself into an economic doom spiral.This is the main reason why most people dislike the game. The interface does not tell you what you want to know and need to know, nor are you given any guidance when your city begins to decline and you have no idea what you did or how to fix it.If you put in enough time to "guess" what you're meant to do to stay in the green, then you reach that level of contentedness, but there are other problems.The game seriously lags in later eras. The game speed slows down dramatically, even on powerful PCs.The political system is easy to beat. There's no need to do any of the political subplot events. Have enough money and goodwill and they'll past nearly every (good) law you bring up. The fact that EVERYTHING you do has to go through the council vote is extremely tedious when 99% of your decisions are guaranteed to pass provided you don't do anything stupid. I do wish there was a more streamlined way to get through the game without having to bring up the Council screen every few seconds.Overall, while I found the game fun enough, the lack of guidance and feedback for the player is an instant-quit for many.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21
												Sorry, this is Fantasy Gameplay with Functional Problems. You can't acctualy play the game without finishing the Tutorial. But the Tutorial does not allow saving the game. This forces you to finish a Tutorial which may last for hours. But the Tutorial has functional problems. Scrolling and zooming does not work well, and not far enough outward to see the big picture. So to see your whole town and important locations around it, this game fails. Tutorial arrows cover information you need to read. Double pop-up screens occur with ghost images over each other. Loading between different sequences takes a long time. Scrolling any menu makes it "bounce" at top and bottom of the menu selection list. Trying to place the rail station while using the mouse to scroll and zoom disconnects the placement of station command many times. After much trial and error in this Tutorial, you find there is only one fixed location for this station on the map but this is untold to the player, so it is not necessarily near where you placed the town at the start. So you can memorize where this was on the map, and then restart the Tutorial to restart the town closer to this station location. When finding it and successfully placing the station, the town council now votes "against" the station. This makes no sense. Why can the player not be aware of this "opinion" before researching and trying to build? And Why did they vote that way? The council does not explain their objection. Poor game design and mechanics. Also the Game as "history" makes no sense. A proposal for Womens Right to Own Property has approval of all parties, but a train station does not! It is the 1820's. Town development does not follow real town development throughout history. Even when using the Dense Grid the town grows like modern suburbia, not like tightly packed houses around a core or town square. Inventions are not historical. Political viewpoints are ahistorical and the Council disagreements on each invention makes no sense for city development. What does this leave? Pretty graphics and a contrived storyline, and you must always use the same contrived player characters. Besides being technically buggy, when the Tutorial does work it has a strange idea of "history" that borders on "fantasy" in gameplay. Not acceptable all around.

I can add services to go bankrupt and make no change... business does seem to do better in mixed district rather than seperated so that I can't save on services...Politics is a joke... Want to raise taxes? Just run a deficit. Doesn't matter how you got there just jack up the taxes. Don't remove whatever you added that ruined the mix. Propose anything they will fight you tooth and nail, oh and count on the party that likes it to be the minority... Let them come to you and it sails through no problem. State laws? it may be unlocked but you cannot propose them and be a trailblazer you just gotta wait until some hidden metric proposes it. I can improve the quality of businesses by "promoting" them but gain no income again only for commercial business because industrial business does not benefit from endorsement what?... the tooltips are missing or unintelligible... I can "cheese it up" but the tools that are suposed to have some impact are equivalent to bashing my head against a wall... I was so looking forward to this game I even preordered, which I almost never do, now I am just dissapointed...  I had so much hope for this.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 21
												TL;DR: Imagine that you have a large amount of candy. You do your best to maintain that amount of candy, while also giving some out to people in need. One day, a man comes up to you and threatens to falsely accuse you of a crime if you don't give the people more candy. Naturally, you give in to his demand, and resolve yourself to producing more candy in order to keep up with this demand. A month later, the man comes back and demands more. You oblige him again. This cycle continues until you have no candy left and all of the people in need are fat and unhealthy. The man approaches you and asks for more candy. When you explain that you have no more candy left to give, he kicks you in the balls and throws you off a cliff. The people that you gave everything to eventually starve to death, cursing your name for not giving them enough. Now imagine that you gave that man $35 to do this to you. That's what this game is like.I was very excited for this game. So excited, in fact, that I pre-ordered it despite my normal policy of never pre-oredering a game. The concept is very intriguing and I've always loved city-building games, so naturally I thought that this would be a good pickup.Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥was I wrong.First off, you walk into this game knowing pretty much nothing about its mechanics because the tutorial doesn't tell you how every action interacts with your city, so you're pretty much blind walking in. In addition to this lack of information, the game punishes you harshly should you ever do something "wrong," so when your profits tank and your citizens start complaining you have no idea why it's happening or how to stop it. Companies go bankrupt for no reason, citizens don't work efficiently or buy things when they're not completely satisfied, and everything costs so much to maintain, so you're either forced to load a previous save or start a new campaign if something goes wrong. A "wrong" action could be as simple as adding street lights to your city, because they will inevitably bankrupt you while not doing a damn thing to help.The citizens are also extremely finicky and hold way too much influence on how the city fares. If *GOD FORBID* you don't give them enough areas to entertain themselves, they'll tank your city in minutes. You are also forced to pick tech trees that don't really have any real benefits other than that they allow you to place a "small park" or a "theatre" in your city, just so you can play the game for more than an hour without losing $50k a month because they can't ♥♥♥♥ing deal with dissatisfaction. Oh, and another fun bit about the buildings  that you're forced to place in order to keep them happy is that they cost exorbitant amounts of money to build and maintain, so you're pretty much doomed to go bankrupt eventually either way. I also can't seem to wrap my head around the fact that a town with less than 2000 people in 1892 needs *AT LEAST* a university, a hospital, several schools, several police stations, 5+ parks, a dedicated seaport, their own train station, electricity, subsidized water/sewage systems, and free ♥♥♥♥ing mass transit in order to not complain and ruin their city's economy. Also, the whole "politics" aspect of the game is essentially useless, except when you really want to save your city (because in that case they'll all ♥♥♥♥ing rally together to block you from making any positive change). You're forced to beg and demand that these city council members give you clearance to satisfy your citizens or save your city from bankruptcy, even though you've been granted your position by the ♥♥♥♥ing Emperor himself and should be completely free to ignore them. Another fun aspect of this system is that your ♥♥♥♥♥y citizens will vote for opposing parties in the next election if you don't completely satisfy their needs, so one party will carry half the votes in the entire council and can block any one of your political moves at will.Eventually, you're forced to hike up taxes to >20% in order to stop the bleeding for a while, but even that will only be a temporary fix. There's no real way to guarantee success in this game, even if you're only prioritizing profits and minimizing funding on the 10+ public safety buildings that you need in order to keep your town with 2000 people in it from feeling dissatisfied.New technology doesn't seem to help with any issues, either, because your citizens will still find a way to screw up your city. Edicts don't work, spying on other parties doesn't work, and frankly, the game itself doesn't really work. You'll suddenly be making $100k a month and you have no idea why it's happening, so you don't know how to keep it from inevitably tanking. These grace periods last JUST long enough for you to propose building up your city's infrastructure and spend most of your saved up money, but almost immediately after you spend some of your security cash your citizens will realize that they only have 3 theatres when they want 4, so they'll stop going to their jobs, all of the businesses and factories in your city will go bankrupt, and you'll be sitting there wishing that you hadn't bought this game or even attempted to succeed in it.This is the most frustrating game I have ever played by far. The thing that makes this hurt so much is that I was really looking forward to it, and that the devs completely botched the execution of this game when its premise was so good. I'm not going to recommend buying it until it's been fixed, or if it's $10 on sale and you're a masochist.

												Decent game but not without its flaws. I really enjoy the hands off approach to city building because I always felt that Simcity and similar titles gave too much free reign as the mayor in my oppinion. The game seriously lacks good explanation for what your actions are going to accomplish and in a few cases there aren't even ways to back out of a decision so that you can check the other options available to you. In general, it feels as though the upkeep cost of improvements are entirely too high especially there's no easy way to get a feel for or really impact the financial health of your city. Most of the issues plauging this game can be easily fixed with a patch, and as I said, balance and explination are my only two real gripes with this game. Oh, and before I forget, the political system also needs to be explained better with the different parties acting as they should (there have been multiple times I've encountered a party proposing something and when you go to the vote screen the proposing party is voting against the bill).

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21
												The good: the game has a brilliant idea. You have either governance games (Paradox) or city builders, but this one marries the two ideas into a hands-on governance game. Few games such as this exist (best one being probably Tropico 4). I think this goes even beyond Tropico in terms of depth, with the existence of formal votes and political parties, so kuddos to the creators for thinking about such an interesting concept.The bad: well, the game gets repetitive very fast, as the political mechanics do the same thing over and over again. There is no sandbox mode per se at this stage, and the optimization is poor. Without the graphics or the underlying mechanics being something to go "wow" about, the game runs slowly and camera controls are wonky. Tropico 5 runs faster and has even better graphics, and larger maps.. Lastly, the interface is horrendous, non-intuitive and difficult to master. Fonts are small, and many players (myself included) had trouble saving the game (due to the insistence on a new save name) or in-game actions due to poor instructions. Sadly, on top of a fairly high cost (at €45 I expect this game not to become a DLC rally point), the poor features make me go for "no" for this game, and I intend to request a refund.

content:
Posted: January 20
												I just hit the 2 hour mark on this game and I had to review it.This game is a great mashup of city builder and political strategy. Sort of a mix between Cities: Skylines, Democracy, Crusader Kings, and Civilization.The game is easy enough to work with, the basics are well explained though I've started over 2 times already because boy does it present a challenge.Growth is limited by both your bank and your political prowess, if you're too against the grain right off the bat anything you try and get done is going to be voted out while if you appease the parties you get some clout that you can use to push your own agenda.One issue that I have run into is the camera, it is much easier to use the keyboard controls for it than to use the mouse ro else you'll end up spinning the camera around wildly and never really get it into the right spot.Placing of buildable areas, called districts, is by far one thing that is really nice. With other city builders every road and zone was placed by hand, now you control how much of what zone type (typical RCI) you want and they are auto placed with roads already there.Want to build a park or a church? You can, using services, though the coucil will need to vote on any changes that are made, unless you're paying for it out of your own pocket. And yes, here you have personal funds as well as city funds and you get paid every month.If you like city builders, strategy games, or political strategy games this is a game you will probably get a lot of enjoyment out of.

content:
Posted: January 21
												Enabled Tutorial.  Task is to create a district.  I create a district just like it says, land area is green for proper size, but the "Create District" button stays disabled.  I'm stuck on the first task unable to complete it.  I restart game with tutorial disabled and am able to create a district without any trouble.  Restart the game with tutorial again, do the exact same process, now it works.  There is a bug in the tutorial for this very first step.   I felt more like a spectator to what was happening than having any control on the outcomes.  After researching Gas Lighting for example I get a screen requiring me to choose between 3 options, A,B,C.  No explanation of the differences of the 3 choices, or even WHAT i am choosing.  I would think gas lighting is gas lightning.  Research complete, install please.  But no, I have to choose option A,B,C. Select option A.  Now I see the effect of that choice being displayed but no way to back up and see what Option B or C does.  My choice of option A is locked in.  This interface makes no sense and no explanation of what or why I am presented with these options. The game has great potential but not there yet.  Needs more work.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 20
												This game needs 3 things very urgently. 1 more interaction with the emporor. 2. make the tools players have to increase income more powerful/consequential. 3. Make the power  a player's action count more towards rewards&punishment.    As of now what can a player do towards helping the economy is too insignificant compared to the random draft, the newspaper is reporting news irrelavent for the player such as what party wins election, instead of news of economy trends that the player can possibly make use of by adopting using tools available. The use of prestige is also very little that it's hardly even a resource to be considered.   And what really happens if you screw up the economy(the only way you can possibly screw up is over expanding btw, since the game omits so much detail for city development)? hardly anything, you just keep watching the unchanging city and wait for your income to sort out itself, passing acts/edicts hardly changes anything, speaking of the acts, they are so numerous, and inconsequential, especially inconsequential withregard to economy which is what a player would care most about, since money decides how much you can do in the game(the other is good will of party, which is meaning less, it's gonna recover over time and brings no threat). And what can you do when you are in a economy quagmire? not much besides maybe re-preportion the district, which is btw FREE by choosing the "use personal funds option".For the most part, you just sit and watch it sorted out. There isn't much you can do, nor is there any pressure for you to do anything, you might as well keep a small district and no one will come punish you as is the case for other strategy games where competition of other players or A.I. players constantly present threat and reminds you what you do counts.     The game seems striving to combine strategy game with city planning, but it fails to be the first due to reasons above and it fails to be the second because it tries to be the first and therefore simplifies all the micromanage details you'll run into in games such as Skyline.

Otherwise so far i have no problem with the game i knew i was buying!Edit: after playing longer i will say that it does get laggy later on even on a decent gaming rig. there are some things that are a little hard to tell what it means aswell. some people say it is to broken to play. i am not having any game breaking issues myself but be warned they are out there to some.if you are on edge because of the bugs and problems. maybe wait some time with any new game and see if there is any changes later you enjoy.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22
												This game is a good example for a good idea, executed very badly and poor. This is a political/economical city management/"tycoonish" game. IMHO: The most important thing in developing a game like this, is game mechanics. Looks like they went for graphics instead. Because the graphics are very good for example. But the game mechanics are terrible. This voting and council system was a very good idea! But for god sake... the votes and the council itself are working like an idiot. For example: Sometimes even if you have a lot of money, they don't want to build anything. They vote no to train station, no to new district, no to everything. My first (and probably the last) try in this game was 2.2 hour. In this more than 2 hours i was able to build: 2 district, a police station, a clinic, and gas lamps. Nothing else. I progressed to almost 1900 but i doesn't feel any "accomplishment". Tho voting and council are working very badly and seemingly (other reviews) random. No real simulation or common sense at all. This is the part where this game fails big time. Not mentioned the sometimes inexplicable childish manifestations in game. I'm very sad.. not expected this. And for last but not least: Very overpriced!If you are fan of the tycoons, manager, simulation, games: Not recommended to buy at all (at any price)!

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21
												This is one of the more interesting city builders I have played. Instead of having absolute authority, you often need to receive council approval to accomplish tasks as mayor. This means you need to plead, demand, threaten, and spy on the political parties to influence their votes. You as the mayor have a resource, 'goodwill', for each of the parties. This represents your political capital and standing with that party. As you cajole, you expend this influence, and if you expend too much goodwill the party will oppose you even if your proposition aligns with their political agenda; they will simply oppose you because they don't like you. As time passes, new technologies are researched, which unlocks new edicts and services that can be purposed to the city concil. Solid 8/10.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22
												You're not a god, you're a mayor with your hands tied who has to answer to the city council and the citizens. It's a challenge. Good luck!Urban Empire has elements of Democracy, Banished, and a little bit of SimCity. But with a lot more variables. Yes, you can create districts, plop train staions and ports, or turn on the gas and electricity. But you're not doing any of that without the votes. You need to make decisions that gain you support of the councillors. While making decisions that are prosperous for the citizens and businesses. It's a balancing act.Although there are several pages of data to ponder while planning your decisions, the feedback is not explained very well. However, after playing more than two or three hours you start to see how it all works together.The graphics and sound are very nice. The UI is well organized and easy to navigate. I have experienced no bugs and it runs fine on my four year old laptop.So for those who are patient, with an interest in politics and city planning, give it a try!

content:
Posted: January 25
												Awesome concept but the game... eh. (would put a sideways thumb but there's no "eh" option)Here are some ways you could improve the game and some thoughts.1.	I can overrule a mayoral race (That’s just silly)2.	Be able to gain favor points with parties other than by waiting or destroying blackmail. (Like by donating to the parties with personal funds or by asking them what policies they want passed)3.	Creation of “Bills” a collection of policies. a.	Reason 1: If there are 12 policies I can pass (Have the funds and are favored by most) I should be able to group them and pass them at one time.b.	Reason 2. If party A and B are opposite on the political spectrum and party A wants a policy but party B won’t let it pass, then group it with something party B wants. (You know like real politics)4.	Higher Density shouldn’t cost so much money. Why does allowing heavier density cost so much money? Higher density = more people = more in taxes.5.	More income methods than taxes would be nice.6.	District size limits is annoying because there are areas that seem large enough but aren’t and are just empty areas. At least let me make it a national park or something.7.	City wide implementation. (If I’m able to implement a service in each district and have the income, and funds then I shouldn’t have to go through each district and have to wait on a vote that will pass no matter what.)8.	More and better cause and effects. (Why is electricity so expensive and costly to maintain? Wouldn’t it be costly to implement then give me a revenue from selling electricity that would offset maintenance?) 9.	Is there no National Government? There should be actual effects of being a city within a national government. (For example If the national government joined/sided with the USSR I shouldn’t be able to be twin cities with San Francisco and Private ownership would decrease or something like that. And if you don’t like being a part of the Country maybe secede or join another country and have a way and effects of doing so) 10.	Am I not in a Political Party? This relates mainly to later eras but shouldn’t I be in a party since I’m a mayor?11.	Political Campaigning for policies and the mayoral race. (For example, if I campaigned for a policy but it was still voted down, but the people “demanded” for it I could overrule it without a negative effect and the parties who voted against it would see a drop in members)

												Ok well i thought i would give this game a fair chance, I always feel at least ten hours is neccisary to employ the tactics and varoius control changes that often occur between these types of games. I have played with all four familes and managed to get to Era 5 twice, gave up on Era three once and am currently in Era 2 with my present game. Swerve this game at all costs as it really is an I-Pad game nothing more. to say this game repeats it self is an understatment. There are so few options in the game that i have exhausted them all and the game plays the same regardless of which family you choose. Its limited beyond comprehension and any reviews (previews) that were out on this game before it was released that praised it should be ashamed of themselves as its so obvious they take back handers from companys and it shows on games like this.Its actually everything that is wrong with the game industry, I can not see how the heap of adons this company will make us pay for can make this game any better? Worst game i have purchased in years and agree that £9.99 would be acceptable and even then only get it on half price offer. I simply cant play it any more and have 1000s of hours on Civ etc. Which i will add if you have not played the new Civ its the best game i have played in years. Very polished, slick and enthralling, Urban Empire is not even a poor rip off of these games its simply garbage ignore all the attractive screen shots im on ultra HD and its really not that great looking. You alos have no involvment with these buildings and all you do is lay a grid that takes a while just to perfect the layout. Best thirty quid i have ever spent as i will never purchase another game by these cowboys.

number of helpful: 13 of 26 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14
												I'm astonished to see this game only has 46% positive. I think this is one of my favorite games to come out recently. The dynamics are unique, at least as far as anything I have played goes, and I really enjoyed them. Unfortunately, I think this is a niche game.I had a brief look at some of the gripes and complaints. Most of them center around "not having control." Well, that's just the thing, folks. In politics, mayor or not, you DO NOT have all the control. At best, you have some sway and a bully pulpit to try and influence things. I think what these folks are looking for is Yet Another Simcity and I have news for those people: This ain't it.To the company that makes this game, I'd say please do not be dismayed. The direction you are going in makes sense and does actually produce a fun game. It is unfortunate that so many people here don't enjoy it but I think that largely is because they were expecting something else entirely.I enjoy politics in real life and that is what attracted me to this game. I really, REALLY hope the devs continue to work on it and update because in spite of this measley 46% rating, I honestly think the game is awesome and definitely fun. It's just unfortunate that so many people who were expecting something else decided to brigade the game's Steam rating. I saw a mention of graphical resolution problem to which I cannot speak, but that is certainly fixable. I have had no such performance of graphical problems, but I have an I7 6700K, 32GB of 3000MhZ RAM, and a Seahawk GTX 1080, so you know, I damn well better not have any issues, lol!Anyway, great game. A really good political simulator, NOT so much a city simulator. It is definitely something different and I really enjoy the crap out of it. =)

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22
												I've seen a lot a people complaining about this game. I waited so long for this game but I did not pre-ordered it (it pisses me off). Well, finally after a lot of reading and watching walkthrough, I decided to buy it. Here is what I think :+ YEAH +- This game is UNIQUE: politics is the center of this construction game. I've never seen it before. So people complaning about the lack of construction in this game: yeah, you knew it! It was said a lot by the developers. I like politics and this game shows something interesting!- Long-life game: this game will provide hours of gaming. Each game will be totally different by your actions, your family and what happens. Maybe not totally at the beginning because some reforms are useful for your city ... But when Era II comes, it changes everything.- Difficulty is gowing slowly more and more difficult ... Era III was a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥- You'll need skills to get your reforms done after Era III because you'll get more parties (up to 6-7) with different opinions, different support of the population (their vote depends about the time but also what your city provides ! More you get schools, the less extremists have chances to get votes).- You get A LOT OF different events that can TOTALLY have an impact on the city: accepting a Lama from a contry, entering in a group of extremists to help your city become independant, chosing a wife etc... A real diversity which makes every game unique.+/- Why not but ... +/-- Didacticial: not so useful. Not mandatory also.- Scenarios: according to me, I did not find fun about it. It can be appreciated for some of you.- NO NO NO ! -- Only 4 families? Seriously? And you ALWAYS begin with the same character ... I would like to get more families and in each family, have a choice of at least 3 different people (because they give bonuses and malus to your city). Seriously, please! -> Be aware that ALL families are unlocked at the beginning of the game so you don't have to play hours to choose.- Public services: really really expensive. And sometimes I don't get bonuses from them. You say Gas help factories, but I've never seen mine getting more money. You'll get hard times guy to get perfect city quickly by upgrading it! You'll need to wait a long time before getting enough money to invest ... Unless politics accept your idea to raise taxes +10% in a year (they can accept +1/2% sometimes).- ONLY 3 MAPS! ARE YOU SERIOUS ???Conclusion:The game may not be, according to me, worth 45€. I did not ask for refund because I have fun with it and I hope they'll get us good upgrades (not DLCs guys). I think this game is worth 20/25€ for the moment (22/01/17). There's a REAL potential about this game. It is UNIQUE because of the system: politics before construction which is really good.I got hope. I give you a 5/7

content:
Posted: January 23
												In a year this will be the best city building game this decade. All of the tools are there for Urban Empire to be the political sim of our dreams, and luckily all of the data the team needs is in the history of cities that already exist. A short list of things I would love to see (apologies if they are in the late game, posted this at around 6 hours played):Issuing bonds on city debtCity council understands that it costs money to create a functioning district. An industrial/commercial district will make more money if employees can pour a glass of water. Companies developing suburban areas (res/comm mix) frequently take on the cost of linking new subdivision infrastructre to utilities. That would be good. City owned utilities producing revenue. Waste removal/landfills as utility/institutionPolitical promises to parties in exchange for votesEarly membership in partiesMore options from the bully pulpit. I should be able to shame the Communists publicly for not giving women the vote. Mayoral campaign control and budgetingPrivate-public partnerships (by now you should know I'm Canadian)Light rail/subwaysMineral royalties from provincial governmentsFederal transfers/grantsSales/luxury/sin taxes (more than liquor and tobacco. I want people to pay taxes on their candy)Hydro-electric powerBidding on government contractsSex scandals ;)The great part is, this all seems easily possible with this design. I can't wait.
