number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22
												I love city builders. However, games like Cities: Skyline gave you complete unilateral rule like a dictator. Tropico was almost the same replacing certain buildings with the idea of zoning that are prevalent in the other games. What I truly wanted in a game as complex as Cities: Skyline was a council that lorded and hounded at every decision I made through the giant political machine hovering over my fair city.Urban Empire was supposed to bridge that gap between city builder and political simulator. Marketed as “Be a Mayor Player”, whatever that meant, you had to develop the city through different eras and leaders through both physical development and the political challenges. You had to develop the city’s society through services while balancing the budget with the city council’s eye on your every move.Oh, what fun I will have!Or, was it a disappointment?Barring you the description of how the “Wheel of Life” (supply/demand for societal expansion) works, let me tell what worked and didn’t.I love the idea of a city council. Frankly, the only reason for me to get this game is because of the idea of city development through voting in a city council. The simulated cityfolk are still allowed to partake in the city’s market economy, but certain services in the Wheel of Life requires the city council’s intervention. Services like fire stations, parks, clinics, opera houses, schools and workshops require that the council vote over the improvement.I also love that the city council has era-appropriate parties occupying the council. My personal favorites were the existence of three parties: The Freedom Party (aka the Nazi Party), The Pacifist Party (super left-wing and liberal), and the Green Party (same like Pacifist Party, but more environmental). Political maneuvering with various parties with different ideologies isn’t a walk in the park. Liberal policies will be unacceptable to some parties, but with the correct development and policies placed into the city early in the game, you can have conservative parties agreeing with leftists liberal policies. The game’s city council rewards players who know how to political maneuver themselves through the era with the easement of passing legislation.However, even with such “coded rewards” written into the game, it suffers from a very counterintuitive user interface. My anecdote is with the idea of banning prostitution and the failed revocation of that law. While the game works on a dual axis binary of conservative/liberal and left/right which works to describe a political ideology, binary shouldn’t be used for your mayor’s decision on certain laws. Like real life, a law passes or fails through the vote of the city council. However, your mayor can only push for a law ahead. If you were to personally revoke a law and convince political parties, they will not push for the revocation. What needs to be worked on are the clarification for the poltical choices of Pleading, Demanding, or Threaten a political party. The developers need to add an additional button to show whether a mayor is pushing to support or oppose if the player makes a mistake.Speaking of mistakes, the performance of this game slows after building a lot of districts. As my trams in some districts zigzag their way through town, the scrolling speed to and fro the city is hampered as building textures load slowly or having serious graphical glitches. The performance has been problem since Tropico 4. Kalypso and the development team at Reborn Games need to calibrate and fix these issues if they were to create sequels. I understand the simulation games are the ones to usually suffer performance issues (like Cities XL), but albeit the game being playable, it becomes an absolute dread as the game stutters dealing with new simulations to compute. Mind you, I was also running my Performance Monitor next to my game and it is a RAM-eater, taking up 7 GBs of memory to run this game, even after adjusting graphic qualities to its lowest.In conclusion, the only reason I am recommending this game is due to its uniqueness of it being both a city-builder and a political simulator. However, I would love the developers to start thinking of this game like a Paradox Interactive game, giving us greater freedom in creating a character and the political situation around the player. I would like them to solve the major performance issues that made this game somewhat unplayable in future eras of the game. Personally, I would return to this game again once they have patched some of the performance and UI issues.

content:
Posted: February 3
A novel game, with an interesting premise, and little handholding (which appeals to me).Govern a city for 200 years, across 5 generations, and attempt to achieve one of 5 victory conditions (ie ala Civilization). Seems like a fairly vanilla premise, until you account for the fact that you do not have absolute power to implement anything.Much/most of what you seek to do will require city council support (via a vote mechanic)  before implementation. Within the council you will deal with a variety of party blocks, representaing a slew of political idealogies, that vary by era. Party support for your proposals, depends upon their ideology/core values, the current economic situation, their relationship with you, and player initiated political interaction (plead, demand, threaten).The game sports a variety of other features, to keep the gameplay interesting, including :  Tech tree (progress cloud),  Emergent events (multiple choices, choices can vary, results influenced by the conditions/charactersitics of your city/mayor),  City/district planning (location, zoning, infrastructure, etc),  Municipal service implementation (police, church, clinic, school, etc), Large scale works (ie railway, port, university, etc),  Economic planning (taxes, service funding, economic edicts, employment),  Governance (state laws, and edicts),  Citizen welfare (social life, health, education, fun etc),  Mayoral elections (start in 3rd era, a loss results in end Progress narrative told through events, newspaper clippings, tech etc.Plenty to do in the game, but little prompting to do it. If you are averse to being proactive (in a gameplay sense) or deducing the "why" behind a given in game result, then UE will quickly become frustrating for you. The game treads a fine line between deliberately obfuscating mechanics for the sake of immersion/depth, and not providing enough feedback on mechanics that really should be made available.  IMO it does not always get this mix right. Some of this is by design, but some is merely a lack of polish and will hopefully be corrected in time.In short, a different take on an established genre (ie city buidling/governance), engaging for those that appreciate depth. Let down by late game performance issues, at times a lack of feedback, and noticeable incidences of primarily polish type bugs (missing tooltips, etc). For me it is refreshingly novel, both engaging and fun, if at times a little frustrating/perplexing. I recommend it.

content:
Posted: January 26
												As a fan of simulations and grand strategy I am loving this game. But beware it is a rough diamond. There are a number of bugs, I personally haven't encoutered any game breaking bugs. My computer is close to the minimum requirements and am running the game on lowest graphic settings smoothly. This means that for me the game isn't very pretty, but for me that is not a problem. The game itself is a new breed of strategy games, much more akin to the Democracy series or Fate of the World, than Civilization franchise or Europa Universalis. There is no combat and during a game you can control one city (others are just diplomatic or trading partners). You can't compare the game to the old school Sierra games Caesar, Pharaoh etc. either as you have only indirect control over industries and commerce. The game is from a small Finnish dev team and I'm Finnish, so I am a bit biased. The game is expensive, but I think it is worth my money. Plus I liked the idea of supporting a small Finnish company.There are scenarios and a grand campaign. The campaign is essentially a freeplay, sandbox game where you begin building a city from a scratch and then have a few ways to finish the game through victory or you can go for the test of time victory condition where you essentially just have to hang on to the power from 1820 to 2020. You can lose votes, but never a mayoral election, that is a gameover situation. In scenarios you start with a ready made city facing a situation  with which you have to cope and there is a clearly defined end-goal.The game itself consists of keeping the citizens happy or at least happy enough and improving the quality of life. In game this is represented by Wheel of Life values, that add up to the general happiness of the population. The happiness of the people affect their the industrial and commercial life of the city, meaning companies and citizens will have more income which you can tax, giving more income to the city. Happiness comes from services the city provides but also form the private sector. If you want to change the city in some way, add services, raise taxes or issue work safety laws you have to go through a democratic voting process. Now the votes. Some people are finding this game shallow, claiming it to be a clickfest. I disagree. I do agree that there aren't very many things the player can do, at least not in a game-mechanic-point-of-view. You can make proposals and parties can make proposals. Then you can try to influence the parties of your view so the vote goes in your favour, majority wins the vote. There is the soft approach Plead, firm approach Demand and the aggressive Threat. Later you also unlock spying which opens up a possibility to use dirt. As a mayor you have a goodwill Value, which is based on events and past incidents in the city, this is the resource that tells how effectively or poorly your threats, pleads and demands go through. There is also a mayoral resource Prestige, which allows you to overturn votes, speed up voting etc. I understand that many frustrated players are just pushing their votes through and thinking that it is a clickfest.I personally am playing the game spending lots of time planning and strategising, looking at my options before starting actual votes, so when I do start a vote, I can tell that it will be easy and effortless to win, without clicking new appeals every month. The other reason for this is that I don't to in a disadvantage if another party makes a proposal I hate. There is a political compass to follow which shows which parties would support or oppose your proposals and by how much. To me this is the best part of the game. At times it is just about waiting to execute a plan at a better time. For me this games political and city-planning elements are definitely what I've been looking for in a game. If you're hesitant there are a number of good let's plays out there, showing off game play and explaining the game mechanics. I'd recommend them very warmly as playing only two hours (for refund reasons) will give, but a small glimpse of the game and maybe not enough to make an informed decision. If you read all the reviews there are many who regret not refunding in time.

content:
Posted: January 21
												Urban Empire is a city-building political strategy game.   This is not your typical city builder.  The main difference between Urban Empire and more traditional city builders is that most everything is put to a vote, so politics and relationships with parties matter. Districts are placed with zoning layouts, services, and infrastructure support. The city council must approve new districts through a vote.  They also will vote on tax rate changes, modifications to existing districts, edicts, and service funding levels. You take control of a mayoral family dynasty and you are required to lead your city and people through 200 years of history (5 eras).  A large variety of events will make each game slightly different. Regarding gameplay, you have to establish infrastructure, plan city districts, debate political decisions at the town council, bribe or blackmail your opponents, empower the democratic rights of your people or ignore them and reign unilaterally. A research tree contains inventions that unlock new services and edicts. Citizens have needs, such as social life, environment, health, and fun. In Urban Empire, you are not only facing problem after problem on how to develop your city, but also how to rule and manage it. There’s big political game behind running of the city, you have to solve the problem and plan what you going to do to run the city effectively through the city council.However, for my taste, the game is too dry.   Determine citizen needs and figure out how to pass it though the city's political power brokers.   I would have liked to interface more with the city, its citizens, and the leaders of the political parties.It's a BIg Chewy - 6.5/10

I wanted a more intricate mechanic based around complex relationships with the city council and citizens that reflectedin votes and decisions. The concepts in the game are amazing and will probably carry the game for awhile, but after I played for a few hours I wasn't having any fun and didn't feel connected to anything in the game.The economy was probably the biggest turnoff for me as it is spiradic at best. It appears that the only viable way to offset costs is to constantly raise taxes. I've been a part of city government for many years and it simply doesn't work this way. Several things, including state and federal funding, for infrastructure and services have been left out. The early eras are understandable in this regard however. Though adding sewage to my districts shouldn't cost me 50k per month for 2,000 people. Wtf are they eating that requires that kind of cost for sewage?!All in all I'm sure this will be an awesome game for alot of people, but it just wasn't there for me. I wish there was a "meh" recommendation on Steam. Maybe Paradox will take a stab at something in this ballpark eventually. Ended up refunding.

content:
Posted: January 21
												I bought this thinking it was a city building game, and there hasn't been many good ones for a long time. However this game is not really a city building game]/b]. Rather it is a city management game.So in city building games you have money, build house (plots), production builds, security, etc and collect taxes and trade to make money back. This game is definitely not that.In current city management games (like Cities Skylines or Sim City) you have money, place zones and the game simulates citizens filling those plots, which you then collect taxes from. This income is then used to pay for services. These often have more tax options and possibly zoning options but it is still very much what you do. This game isn't that.In this game it tries to portray eal city management. You can't just place plots or build structures, there is a city council that has to weigh the benefits of an option. If you want to expand the city, you need to design a zone, then propose that to the city council. A political party or more may oppose this, but you can appeal to them. However if you have bad finances don't expect the vote to pass. Almost every action goes to a vote.The game is set in a pseudo-realistic time, and as time passes new technologies are invented (game explains that technologies that you unlock are from you importing them to the city). The newspaper that pops up includes references to things that happened in that year in the real world.This is a slow game, and you end up having to struggle to balance the budget. The politics can also get quite intriguing. So be prepared, if you don't like slow games with lots of reading then stay away.The game itself runs fine for me, no issues there.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20
												I'm a huge fan of the Tropico series, by Kalypso, so naturally I was excited to see this title coming out.  I pre-ordered it, and almost right away I could tell this was not the game for me.Basically, all they had to do was give us a more polished version of Tropico, with a more in-depth political model.  They attempted to kind of do that, but then changed the building process (and ease of).  For instance, in order to even build your city, you basically have to build "wards" and plan out their outlines.  And interesting concept, but totally un-needed and annoying.  Then the game is basically goes into auto mode, building it's own houses and such, where it wants to ... which totally disrupts your plan for city buildings such as police stations, schools, etc.On top of that, after you place a "ward," it's then broken into different zones, residential, industrial, etc.  From what I can tell, it just randomly assigns these zones, depending on the terrain.  Again, totally annoying and screws up the building process.   30 minutes in, and I still can't figure out how to place the Train Station.  It really shouldn't be this difficult or clumsy.Tutorial is a joke.Luckily I a got a refund.So TLDR:Clumsy, complicated building and planningControl taken out of players hands/ distributed by random assignmentPolitics not really engaging  All we needed was a polished and engaging build-off from Tropico ... but they threw the best parts of Tropico outMusic and sound, meh.

content:
Posted: January 22
												Reading through some of these reviews, and some of them are pretty heavy handed.  So instead of pros and cons, praises and complaints, expectations vs. realities.  I'll just give you what it is. Macro Manager:  There are very few things that you actually place aside from the district layout and select services. Political Player:  Work your way around 3+ political parties who vote on every single decision that you make that requires funds or increasing taxes.  But use your political favors wisely, as eventually you will have to run for reelection. Popular Populist:  Meet the needs of your people through six avenues all of which add up to their overall happiness.  Techological Leader:  Work your way through an expansive tech web that starts with advancements from the 1800's all the way to modern times.  Each tech gives you expansive capabilites and services that you can improve your town with.  Financial Guru:  This is the most important.  Without profitable revenue, you will go no where.  Which is really easy to do.All these requires a balance to get you through the game.  Some need a lot of attention, while others will sneak on you at the worst possible moment.  My biggest piece of advice is to restart as soon as you get a grasp of the mechanics of the game.  The tutorial goes too slow, and your district building should be rapid in the early game.  Overall, I recommend this game to those who are curious about the macro style mechanics of the game and do not mind throwing a few extra bucks at a developer who tried to do something new and interesting.

content:
Posted: February 2
												This is a strange one.A mix of almost impenetrable mechanics, terrible UI, beautiful graphics, incredible atmosphere, intriguing plot, and strangely addictive gameplay.It is not for the faint-hearted and took me over a week to start to understand how the deep game mechanics even work. That said, it is a really fascinating game, and one in which i became oddly invested in. There's something really satisfying about seeing your city grow and prosper, whilst you slowly introduce more and more technology and social changes.As I said, a very atmospheric simulation, which I have spent over 41 hours on since release.BUT....do not buy this game expecting it to be anything like a normal city builder - it is certainly not that.Also, do not expect to understand the mechanics without reference to youtube videos. they are obscure to say the least. This issue is made much worse by the worst UI choices I have ever seen....improving profitability is expressed by a Negative number, highlighted by a red text box! Red=good in this game apparently. But, if you can stomach these issues, the game is really satisfying, and overall, worth the purchase, if only to experience a whole new Genre of game.

												Just a couple hours in, but I like it for the most part. The dynamics of managing parties and getting the city council to vote are quite well done. Placing districts, doing research, voting, etc., all make sense and are easy to get used to. Overall I'd say this game is Tropico meets Civ 6 or SimCity city planning. However, I didn't figure out how to modify existing districts or how to add dervices to districts already populated. Maybe I am missing something here, but why can't I repurpose land and put a school where a house used to be? Also, after reserching tech, how can a district be upgraded to have gas lighting or a swer system? I'm sure these things must be available, but the tutorial mode didn't point them out and I couldn't figure it out on my own.The one thing I found very annoying was the inability to save my game. Clicking on "save" just prompted the script saying "Saving is not permitted at this time" or something like that. Not sure if the game needs an update to "save game" or if games that have progressed beyonf era 2 can be saved or something???

content:
Posted: January 22
												Really loved the depth in this game ; lots of choice and a lot of political realism ; what I would love to see for an expansion would be more scenarios such as the WWI period and the revolutions that followed.  Maybe stuff in response to the Great Depression and World War Two.  Also I take it the early game is based on the Austro-Hungarian Empire.  Historically the Austrian Social Democrats were Marxists until they were crushed by fascism.  BTW I'm only up to the 1920s so far - so I don't know what comes after.  Sometimes I think I'd rather a scenario based on leading a Party rather than a single Mayor ; But who am I to complain?  This game fixes lots of the problems I once associated with the Genre.  A progressive welfare state is viable without ideological assumptions in the scripting which rule out social democratic strategies.  I really hope expansions and mods follow this ; Its really good so far - but I'm sure it could be better.  One last thing that annoyed me:  I hung on as Mayor in the 1920s but I can't seem to shake the right-wing parties ; I'm still getting good legislation through ; But it would be nice to have strategies capable of turning the tide in favor of the left-wing parties...  BTW the Communists also often play a spoiling role early on - which is not historical...  The self-proclaimed Communists parties arose in response to the split in European social democracy on account of World War One....

												I have thoroughly enjoyed this game. There was a gap in the sim/strategy market for a balanced political-economic-rts and I think they have really plugged into that gap. That being said, there are a few issues that leave the game needing some polish. I have only had one critical issue which was having the game progressively slow until I had to turn it off and re-open it - haven't had it since. Other than that it's little things here and there: things spelt wrong, descriptions vague and unnecessary, not being able to micromanage the distribution of a district, some things are in the tutorial but critical success points aren't, etc. None of these have taken away from the base simulation which I can say is a lot of fun to play with. Definitely recommend for the genre fanatics (like myself), but wait for a sale otherwise.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21
												Most positive reviews I've read share similar views to myself; it's enjoyable but needs some polish.There are a lot of negative reviews that criticise the devs choices on mechanics; whilst all aren't exactly as I like them these were pretty darn clear before purchase and I think some people weren't expecting a dev to have opted for a defined stream of choices (so many let you do that for yourself or at least give you an option between the two models). Overall, I actually like what the dev has gone for and there is a robustness to the path, plus I had bothered to read and knew that wasn't a feature offered (I don't think it's reasonable for the devs to have been expected to say "we aren't doing XYZ", that's ludicrous and some people need to grow up and face reality).There is nothing game breaking wrong with the game and all bugs I’ve faced are minor. In this day and age this is laudable; especially as unlike most niche games they didn't go down the god-awful route of early-access abuse (in some cases it can be useful, but I have too many games I've given up on and a good while later they still haven't been 'released').The strategy is light but with a subtle complexity (political consequences for example only really affect the short to medium term). It's fun and light without being too easy. As I found out today, some challenges cannot be overcome in terms of your design choices if you truly make a mess at the beginning - just because it works for Era II doesn't mean it won't destroy you in Era III / IV. I actually expected there to be little replay value during my first couple of hours of play, though this changed after I got booted out at election time and realised it had got more engrossing and I could plan for this particular challenge differently. That's a good thing - losing actually made me want to try to do it differently and have another go!Oh, and for those whining about it being 'slow' or little to do (I suspect this is earlier on, but as your edicts increase and need to balance more parties and tweak a dozen or more districts this changes), 4X speed is your friend.The only real downside for me is the price - £35 is the wrong price point. It's £25 on Amazon and that is a much more appropriate price point from a value perspective. I appreciate that niche games sell less and thusly they have a harder job of finding the right price to give the necessary profit overall, but I suspect some of the whinging would have been reduced if the pricing was right. Plus – they make less from a retail sale as a % of sale price, which in itself is lower, so why on earth have a Steam price so high. Let’s assume steam is similar to Apple et al and give the dev/publisher 70% - that would still be considerably higher than what they get from a retail sale and they would sell more at the higher % on Steam if they priced accordingly – remember, they sell to a distributor who sells to the retailer (who sells at only 71% of the Steam price on Day 1); plus the delivery costs included at all of those stages – so let’s assume the dev/publisher gets at best 40% of their Steam sale price for each retail sale (I think that’s high). It always baffles me why they don’t price more wisely on Steam, get more sales there, and therefore more cash overall whilst at the same time keeping the gamer happy. Sorry, rant over.

content:
Posted: February 2
												Seems like kalypso pushed this out of early access too soon. Would post neutral if possible. Rating positive because the game has some merits and it has enough negative reviews already. Pros:-Story/flavour is quite good-Sound is good-All around generally enjoyable for the first 10 hours or soCons:-Missing tool tips -Lack of transparency in terms of game mechanics-Performance issues for LOTS of people that have a decent size city-Tedious city council (you need to watch the votes being tallied for around 10s every time you do something with no way to skip the animation, gets very old when you need to watch this 200+ times in a play through)-Can cheese the tech system (internet etc in 1860s), possible to complete the entire tech tree before the outbreak in WWI-No real downside for adopting rapid change in your society, there is a mechanic where people will need more amenities to be happy years later but these needs increase over time regardless. Resisting change will only make your city a backwater, unable to provide more amenities when they want them later on.-Political party ideologies are not represented properly and rarely change with the simplistic political compass. Eg the communists will support things lower taxes on the wealthy and are pro church because authoritarianism and conservatism are not separated. For the same reason why fascists will oppose things like youth sport, promoting national culture etc because they classed as socialist (national socialists aren't socialist?) and/or liberal policies. Good concept, bad execution/possibly unfinished.

content:
Posted: January 22
												First of all - this game SHOULDN'T be compared to city builder games because it has a completely different approach to the city management with more emphasis on the family, politics and different era characteristics. You actually kind of macro-manage districts with not much room to manipulate like you are able to in typical city builder games. The game leads you through some of the most interesting eras of modern history, with all the global crisis affecting your little city as well. You develop technologies to boost your industry and commerce, propose edicts to balance out some of the issues you might have in your city, you make taxing changes etc. In my opinion, it all feels moderately complex although it has quite a lot features.Now the biggest problem that I personally have with the game is the transparency. After a couple of play-throughs I still have no idea why some of the issues appear in this game and I cannot pinpoint the source of the problem in order to find a way to resolve it. I feel like the game is missing more clear UI, explanation of the various stats that your companies have that affect their success, and so on. There should be a lot better advisor system in my opinion.Overall - the game is fun and it has a kind of a fresh approach to the city game genre. It does make you play it a couple of times which I tend to value the most in games. However it does not justify the price. It should be priced at about 20$ at most because it lacks the complexity to be valued more. 6.5/10

content:
Posted: January 21
												5 Hours to Boredom, that's how long it took me to "shelve" this game.........No muliplayer...in this day of age?  No interactive elections in a game like this? You can't modify family names from the weird given names?  Is there more to this game?  Only 3 senarios, 1 campaign and no sandbox?  Only 4 families and no ability to modify attributes at all? Slow to load (I7 and 650M card, 32gb) and clunky between screens, less than average graphics, and the font size is so small you can barely see it.  I know there's a fun game in there somewhere?  I'm still working on finding it!  But, this game has some real problems.  The playing of the game starts out interesting up until you figure out just how repetitious it is.  Voting is the high point of the game, and as soon as that gets boring, it's all down hill from there.  I love the subject matter, and I just had to have it.  I hope the modder community will give this game some real time....because it could be a great game, but now, in its current state, it's an, "okay" game.   Am I going to have to wait 2 years for an Urban Empire 2?  Or, buy countless DLC's to finally have the polished game this could be?  NOT worth the price I paid over 30 bucks even with the pre-release special....I would wait until the price drops, because it will...  It's not worth a negative rating, just a bland so/so, "hope it gets modded and added to"  so, it's a 5/10 rating for me.

And just because the parties will support you doesn't mean that decision is right. I buried my first campaign when my economy began to slide and all parties (regardless of their hate of taxes) supported raising them month over month to save the budget... Which of course led to bleeding my people and businesses dry. Every tax I raised led to LESS money in my coffers. You can't always trust the politicians, and you have to be intentional and sometimes fight the council with all you have for the good of the city.This is exactly what I wanted to play.

												Over-all this game largely met the kind of expectations I had for it. It set out to be a game based around being a dynasty of politically important figures in a city. It gives you benefits for focusing on various aspects, and you usually are restricted in just how much you can do with your city. While it's possible to obtain a strong enough enough economy to achieve multiple goals it seems nigh impossible to do all of them.This game has a dash of Sim City, Democracy, and even a few key elements of it's own. It's not an amazing game, but it does seem like an entertaining game even if it has a hard time showing exactly how certain aspects impact your city.

Posted: January 21
												A fun little AA city sim.  Part story focused, part city builder, part politics sim, this title aims to do it all.  While not a perfect game due to being too ambitious, I certainly enjoyed the eras and the story of the characters you play as.  I would pick this game up if you want to wittle away the time for awhile building citys and seeing how technoloy changed the eras.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20
												What I like about this game is that it adds more of a realistic feel to it than other games for example SimCity. In this you have to fight for what you believe for witht he city coucil. Its not supposed to be a you say it goes type of game and I like that, it brings a new combination of city bulider, simulation and stratgey. A mix that we don't see much of in the gaming world. We grew tired of seeing SimCity after Simcity, F1 after F1 (simualtion- kinda) and all of the tycoons. This adds a new mix to entice us. The Devs knew what the gamers wanted. Especially in this field of games, you always see Black Ops and Battlefield in other fields, this is exactly what we wanted in the stratgey/ city bulider field. The game is unpredictable and I like. For example I play through era 2 and I create 5 new districts with all the support I needed. I play through it again and I have to ask the empire for money. Great game totally worth $40, no doubt. Amazing game Devs. LOVE it.

content:
Posted: January 21
												In the mere 12 hours that I've owned this game, it has crashed 4 times, 3 of those crashing the whole PC, one to blue-screen.  That would be a pretty severe indictment of an early alpha release, and terrible for a beta version, but Urban Empires is supposedly a full release, ready for prime time.  There's no way on earth I could recommend this software while it is so unstable as to crash a well-specced Win 10 PC so continually even if it were a free game, so I certainly encourage everyone to resist actually paying to have their PC crash, data lost, etc.If the game interests you, as it obviously did me, then I strongly urge that you wait for a more stable and fixed version.

Posted: January 21
												I'm halfway through my first game and enjoying it.  Creative take on city building/ruling with potential.  Takes a bit of trial and error as some of the game mechanics are still too opaque (e.g. sales demand).  But I'm getting the hang of it.  There aren't as many levers as a city builder, but that makes for less micromanagement, and there is still plenty to do.

content:
Posted: January 22
有更好阅读体验的图文版链接[cowlevel.net]Urban Empire：食之无味，弃之可惜。我们在梦想与进步中长大。1820年，皇帝赐了你一块地，给了你500k的个人起始资金和1000k的城市资金，作为城市的创建者，从下手划分第一块行政区起，你将要开始你的市长生涯。而这个城市的名字，你把它叫做“Kaisershafen”（要是你没改名的话）。在最开始的阶段，只能建造一个低密度、仅有最基本的基础设施，甚至连分区比例都无法自定义的行政区，开始走向小城崛起的道路。Kaisershafen的繁荣发展与别处是不同的，他麻雀虽小，但确人才济济——什么热力学、流行病学、炸药、电子游戏等等，都将在这里被发明。不要怀疑，是虽然表面上是发展云，但是研究完成一个之后会让你选择下一个“发明”，想来诺贝尔、开尔文这样的人物都蜗居在这个小城，这样一个小地方何愁不兴旺发达。甚至将来自己发射个卫星，也不是不可以。更难能可贵的是，这里还是人权斗士的运动基地，什么劳动法、女权、环保、动保，在这里都可以看到他们活动的身影，性爱革命、消除歧视这样的运动也是说“发明”就“发明”，端的是“世界何其大，发展靠我家”。虽然Kaisershafen在地球上占据了这么一个举足轻重的位置，但是也不固步自封，世界之大，我市伸出友谊之手，堪堪选出了6个未来入得了法眼的城市：牛津、旧金山、悉尼、圣彼得堡、上海、仙台，虽不是首都，但也横跨世界五大洲，哦不少了个非洲。但先不急，先把眼下这个小镇子经营好吧。钱，钱，钱！城市发展之本，便是资金了，如何让运营城市的成本低于带来的收益，便是发展首要的问题。每建立一个行政区，都需要额外的成本，而人口的增长和行政区数量的关系尚不明确，所以要慎重创建新的行政区，在有需求的时候再建岂不稳妥得多。发展的步子也不能迈的太大，不能将无法承担的基建一股脑儿的往城区上般，而要走一步看一步，先找个试验田看看带来的收益能不能值回成本，再考虑是否将这个推广。这本是一个城市发展的应有方式，然而UE内部经济循环的不明确导致就算成本一时没有把握，城市入不敷出眼看走向崩溃，依然可以靠不断提高税率来弥补漏洞，而此时本是用来制衡市长行为的议会，居然也会用脚投票，只要不结余太多的提税提案，通通通过。也尝试过降低税率来观察是否能通过刺激消费带来收入的提升，但结果是虽然有略微的提升，但是效果远不如直接调节税率来的明显。虽然高税率之下随处可见破产企业，但是城市收入还是稳步提升，人民也过得幸福如意，简直匪夷所思。压榨人民制定高税率，虽然日子当下过得有些紧，但在研究完一项科技、时代更替下，收入能实现稳定的增长，日进斗金不是梦。正所谓“降税容易提税难”，赶早变着法从市民手中抠钱才是硬道理。我最喜欢胁迫他人了既然提到了议会，那就不能不说说这个游戏的议会系统。由于前几个时代皇帝钦定了玩家来做这个市长，完全不怕被弹劾，也不怕有竞争者的出现，本来用来制约玩家用来改变法案支持率的“政治货币”党派好感度，尤其在不能跌破下限-10的情况下，其本身意义也然无存。在好感度为正的情况下，恳求非常有效，一旦跌到负值，那么胁迫反而变成了最容易的途径。议会便犹如一个玩具，任由玩家揉捏。就算是后期出现了竞选也无妨，只要城市发展良好，每两个月去稍微胁迫一下每个党派，市长位置还不是手到擒来。每6年一次的选举，也不过就是消耗我“政治货币”的途径而已，和之前已经不同至于与经济相关联的提案，只要城市日进斗金，财务无忧，不管有什么政治诉求这些党派都会无脑通过。我造的我来毁随着城市的发展，城市密度需要由低向高发展，来容纳更高效率的住房、工厂和商店。然而，在此之前已经建立的建筑物无法自动更新，于是中后期拆迁（需要科技解锁）就变成了一项很常见的工程。虽然看着一座座房屋轰然倒塌是一件很爽快的事情，但是一个区域那么多建筑，一个个点过来确实非常的累。在没有框选和快捷键的条件下，一个个选中建筑，移动到右下角摧毁，在到屏幕中间确认选择，然后一片区域重复几十次，是一件很傻B的事情。虽然拆迁需要付出一定的代价，相应建筑物带来的利润也会随之失去，但是之后新建筑慢慢拔地而起，带来的利益也是明显的，只是太繁琐的操作容易让人失去耐心，所以我都是在区域比例分配那里先全选成住房，确定改变区域后，再全选为工厂，提交改变，用私人资金改后，再手动分配比例，反正改变区域比例不要钱，所以用自己的钱也就不需要提案，区域人员的安置赔偿都不用管，虽然也要动好几下鼠标，比一个个摧毁省力多了。虽然这样就不能解锁拆迁成就了自由，平等，博爱！关于人权的问题，一直以来都是现实生活中争议颇多的地方，在这个游戏中也是。琳琅满目的提案，有些就算放到当前来看也是尚未实现。比如同工同酬、同性婚姻合法化等等。非常的pc，倒是我喜的部分。退化完成最后说说这个游戏其他方面的质量。游戏汉化不易，但是这个汉化的质量确实有点垃圾。比如前文提到的“发展”和“发明”指的是同一个东西；比如“少数名族”的同性恋问题；再比如将LGBT翻译为“同性恋”；再比如本段标题的“退化完成”，而英文原文是“Downsizing done”。而只在科技完成时出现的原本就不多z中文语音中，我竟然还在其中听到了一条英文语音，不过我倒是忘了记下是哪一段。没玩过游戏就翻译，以及缺少统筹校对，是很多已有汉化的通病，这个游戏汉化该有的也都有。游戏本身其他的硬伤也不少：1.流程单一，一个家族就是一个既定的事件，没有重复玩的价值。三张战役地图大同小异，也就是地形稍有区别，反而是三个挑战还有那么点意思。2.优化烂，游戏进行到后期卡的不行，载入及保存时间长，常常未响应让人以为程序崩溃。玩着玩着程序崩了的情况也有发生过。3.内部经济逻辑不清前面已经提及，进入下一个时代只不过就换了个接班人，收入却猛的增加，着实让人捉摸不透。4.成就系统混乱不堪，目前成就各种张冠李戴。5.画面，嗯感受一下高楼大厦吧（？乐观者说，这玻璃杯里有一半是满的。悲观者说，这玻璃杯里有一半是空的。工程师说，这玻璃杯只要有原来的一半大就够了。同样的一句话，送给这个游戏，这游戏内容看似丰富，实则浅尝辄止，壳子只要有现在的一半就够了。当然如果你是乐观者，可以玩一玩。

content:
Posted: March 3
												This game is fantastic.  I will admit, it has a large learning curve.  The creator of this game made an excellent new genre of City Building, Real Time Strategy, and Turn based gaming.  I have been playing city builders since the original Sim City.  This game has all of the fun of those games, with an added element of politics.  You must learn to work with, and destroy, the political parties to get the things you want passed.  This makes it a very realistic game, and fun once you get the hang of it.

content:
Posted: February 19
												I actually enjoyed this game---it's a bit different than other city builders I play. I have to think through decisions---build another district? Or repave the existing ones. Then there's the costs. Nothing's free. It's closer to real life than people think (in the real world, I do this kind of planning. It's probably why I still play city players.)I haven't yet experienced any of the bugs, although some of the spellings are odd. A copy editor should have run through the game before release.Other than that, I'm having fun playing.

number of helpful: 3 of 10 people (30%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23
												Good game. An interesting political and economical simulator.+ Reasonably difficult, you can be voted out in eras 3-5 if you're on bad terms with the political parties+ Depicts the history in an interesting way, you can feel the world changing over time+ Keeps you invested in the game, presents the player with challenges even in the late game (for me it was actually the hardest party-wise in the late game)- Hard to understand the reasons behind what is happening at times (e.g. persistent low residential demand, constant influx of lower class citizens). Tooltips like the ones in Victoria 2 would be welcome. Many things may be not evident, like what exactly the tax rate does, I think at least an explanation would be good in such cases.- Some things that you expect would happen, don't. E.g. people moving between the districts or preferring particular ones- Watch your RAM and save frequently on the later stages, the game crashed to desktop for me around year 2010, for some other people too (8GB RAM)All in all, I spent the weekend playing the game and had good fun, in my opinion that makes the game deserve a good recommendation despite some issues which may or may not be resolved later.

number of helpful: 3 of 10 people (30%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22
												I strongly disagree with most of the bad reviews on this page. I am in no way supporting the game just because I spent money on it. I usually play grand strategy games such as Crusader kings and etc. and also great city building games like cities: Skylines. This is a totally different type of game. It is not action packed in anyway. It is cool that you indirectly lead a city. Your family is a mayor and you can control districts, edicts, and government buildings and it is tough because there are polital parties that have different views and always vote on everything in the city. You work through the eras like this and trying to balance a city and personal budget. It is much slower paced and a different take on city building and management. Please take these into consideration.

content:
Posted: January 20
												There's just something about this that feels.....shallow.  I like the idea that you're basically playing as a mayor of a town and are limited by what the legislature says (aka what happens in most towns in western societies with a mayor and council governing system)....but.....something is off.For one, the UI system is a bit crowded and overwhelming.  It's in sad need of being overhauled.  Don't get me wrong, I'm not trashing it because it's complex.  Complex is good if it's organized (aka Europa Universalis IV) but this is just a mess.Maybe this can be fixed in patches?  Then again, maybe not.  For now, what a shame.  This could have been something new and fun.

content:
Posted: January 22
												Great Game, I have already logged 5.5 hours and I can tell you that it is exactly what I expected it to be. It IS NOT a city builder, it IS NOT a political simulation, IT IS a simplified simulation game where you are a mayor, make rules, set standards, place structures and WATCH your empire evolve. I recommend this game to all the hard core fans of Tropico that would have liked to have more political input and law making abilities; and less city building/managing and more city evolution watching. It's honestly a good game for the price, some changes I recommend after my first play through.PLEASE FIX OR ADD:- Allow districts to be named longer, I wanted to use Pioneer District and realized it was cut off around "Pioneer Dis", I'm sure allowing longer names is an easy fix. I felt like I had to overthink naming and find one that fit.- While modifying districts, modifying taxes, modifying services... there should DESPERATELY be a function that allows me to go back a page/tab. For example, I open up modify district, I confirm the zoning, then the second menu pops up and asked me to confirm the services... there should be an option that allows me to go back to zoning and re-edit. Maybe like a back arrow in the top left. This would be extremely useful because sometimes I find myself going in and out and re-doing the modify district settings until my proposition pleases the council.- Some things are way to overpriced, like lamps. I would propose you do a full re-vamp of the prices in-game.- I would like simple road contruction. That way I can place my districts anywhere in the map and connect them via road. That way I can have them distanced by each other, and just like reality... each district should be ran by a different set of rules and you should be able to propose eddicts to seperate districts.- And FINALLY!!! SHOW ME WHAT A CHOICE WOULD AFFECT (This is my biggest recommendation!). For the love of all things merry... When a choice needs to be made and "I have to choose what to tell the engineers of the railroad bridge" please tell me what each choice would do to me. I understand that the game was designed to allow the player to make choices and those choices affect you down the line randomly... but sometimes I like to make choices based on what they affect.

content:
Posted: January 29
												Fairly hard learning curve, and you currently aren't able to save during the "tutorial," which takes upwards of a few hours (god forbid you need to leave your house at some point in the day...). Overall, it feels as though the game wasn't quite field-tested enough before release, and certainly needs continual patching.Since release, we've already seen a few patches, mostly fixing random, small bugs, rather than the larger problems in the game, such as lack of maps/map diversity, only having 4 families (character groups) to choose from, and the extremely disproportionate cost of things like infrastructue and amenities such as theatres to income potential. In addition, even if you play the tutorial to the end, a lot of the basic game mechanics go essentially unexplained, such as the importance of district infrastructure, density/spread, and how employment/business bankrupcy works.It's definitely a good game, with a lot of potential, and I do recommend picking it up if it goes on sale, but it's not a must-have. With time, and a dev team that cares about fixing it, Urban Empire could definitely be a game to rival the great city-sims of the gaming world.

												This is a game based on a great idea and that have the basic feature of a promising game. It's clearly not finished. There is many thing to add and to correct. First, the pace. After a fey playthrough, I feel that science is going a bit weirdly. When I was at the 4th age, evens talked about computer, but my city was still without electricity... An other time, I arrived in the 60' without having upgraded any road or anything... Second, party act a bit weirdly and unpredicably. There is no clear link between district and election of one or another party. I wanted to have a very egalitarian city, with no "upper class" district with more services... and there was none... but I wasn't able to see if it has any effect in the election... and there is absolutely no info about the relation between the population and the party...Third, I felt in many games that I even had no effect of the party themselves. I wanted to be close to one and he was rejecting me for no reason...Forth, and it was noted in many review, the policies are not clearly organised on party lines...Still, I recommend the game, because the idea is good, it is still fun and, like the game from paradox like Europa Universalis and Crusader kings, I have hope that it's just a vanilla game on wich will be built many DLC that will make this game great again! ;)

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22
												I'm really enjoying this game -- managing relationships with political parties, begging/forcing what I know to be best for the city, trying to not burn so many bridges that I can no longer be re-elected...all while pushing for equal rights for all citizens, advancing technologies, etc.I also enjoy the deep-dive you can do on stats.  At one point in the year 1914, I discovered that my town of ~3000 people had a whopping 22 movie theaters, and the number one employer of middle class citizens?  Movie production companies.  I'm a burgeoning Hollywood!The biggest minus is that the game frequently freezes on my laptop, AND THERE IS NO AUTOSAVE ABILITY.  I have to remember to manually save every year or so.Also, a lot of things are unexplained in the game...even in the tutorial...but I liked trying to learn as I went along.  I will say I was disappointed to see that things like electricity and plumbing didn't really change the look of my city.  In fact, the technological advances don't seem to actually advance technology at all.  People in my city were driving cars before we discovered the combustible engine which unlocks the automobile.  My entire city was on the telephone grid before we had electricity.  Perhaps most egregious, my character had to win re-election before citizens actually had the right to vote.But all in all, this is a new kind of game and I'm fully on board with where it's going.  8/10.

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23
												Despite the resemblance to other city-builders such as SimCity and Cities: Skylines, Urban Empire is first and foremost a political simulator.  You play the role of mayor of a city located in the fictional nation of Swarelia and you'll be responsible for guiding your city through five different time periods, from the industrial revolution to the modern era.  Like the city-building games mentioned before, you will oversee the growth and development of your city, zoning residential, commercial and industrial districts as well as adding service buildings (police stations, hospitals, churches, etc) and issuing edicts.  However, you do not rule with absolute authority - the decisions you make are subject to approval by the city council.  The council is made up of multiple parties, each with their own agenda, so it may be necessary to appease the voters order to get them to see things your way.Here is a quick run down of the pros and cons of this game.PROS:- Good quality graphics - any changes are visually displayed on the city view screen such as adding street lights or upgrading roads from dirt to cobblestone, etc.- Extensive tech tree that allows you to upgrade your city in a variety of ways.- Detailed statistics screens on a variety of subjects.- Game features multiple dynasties to play as, each with their own strengths and weaknesses, adding some replayability to the game.- The political wheeling and dealing you engage in is quite fun.- Detailed tutorial that offers advice as you play the game.CONS- Some of the statistics can be a little confusing.- The UI is not the friendliest.- While the tutorial is detailed, it can also be intrusive at times.- There aren't that many maps to play on.- Gameplay can feel repetitive at times, I suspect the developer is looking to flesh this out with DLC.- The city-building aspect is a little basic.CONCLUSIONOverall, it's a fun game that's not without its flaws.  If you enjoy city-builders, but are looking for something a little bit different, I think you will like this.

number of helpful: 3 of 12 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24
												So... you want to play Sim City + The Guild? You're in the right place.I've only finished my first full play through. I started once before and realized I had not set myself up for success very well.In the early stages, it seems you want to nail down getting some districts up. Things must be at least somewhat large for your city to make income. You definitely want your city to have money. The politicians are very reluctant to let you do just about anything if you don't have money in the bank for it.I think some people are disappointed because their vision was just a little different than what the game is. One aspect of this is the way I hear some people describe the game as basically on rails. Those criticisms range from choices having no affect at all to revisionist history not being possible.I think the game has more depth than people are immediately aware of. I also think making it through will be a challenge.There is some degree of "riding waves" here. I wouldn't say things are on rails because it isn't such a fair criticism since I'm pretty sure there are tons of different rails. The trick is getting your train on different tracks. You control technology, so you have decent control over what edicts hit the table. You can also sway public opinion so that different parties gain and lose public favor.I made it up to the third era but was voted out of office.The game definitely forces choices, but it seems this is very intentional design. The game isn't always about steering the ship exactly where you want. It's more about looking at the available options and making the best choices at the time so that you have more power to steer somewhere you want.I think the game is good, and there are still three other houses I haven't tried yet. At somewhere around $2/hr, I'd definitely say it's worth it.They do need to address performance issues, however. The game doesn't seem to be able to handle a whole city. I have a fairly good rig and it is sluggish with pretty much all graphics options turned off. Maybe lowering the resolution would help more, but really?

content:
Posted: January 24
												A city builder with teeth. Finally. I won't sugar-coat it: there are flaws. The simulation underlying the mechanics is obtuse and REALLY needs more info exposed to the player while in-game, but a few hours playing with it will tell you a lot. Just don't expect to "win" on your first, second, or even third attempt. It also needs more agency on the part of the AI - the city council can stop you from doing things, but rarely does anything that would benefit the city itself. I'd like to see them propose districts on their own to help out stuck players, because it's easy to get into a situation where you're bankrupt and unable to advance, and there's only one gameplay event that helps with this. I'd also like more maps, more variety of history events for the various families (or even a random family altogether), and an ahistorical mode to help replayability. But as the game is, currently, it's still fun and worth the price.

number of helpful: 1 of 9 people (11%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29
												The concept is great, one I have often thought about and I give the developer kudos for trying to deliver it.  I feel like it will get to a better point soon with the patches.The pros:Voting and party goals are clear, persuasion seems pretty well done.Reactive events based on city conditions are nice.City advancing through time is pretty good as well.Simulation is pretty deep in most places.Historical accuracy seems pretty good.The cons:UI has missing tooltips, confusing tooltips, tons of information about stuff but does a poor job explaining what those numbers mean.  Very hard to figure out why businesses are doing well or poorly.Social class seems tied strictly to education, too much education in your town and you run into a shortage of working class people and your businesses suffer from lack of efficiency, too little education and you run into a shortage of middle class people and your businesses suffer from lack of quality.  Could use some flexibility to let working class step up as managers and let middle class do manual labor and migrate classes that way.  An end game tech automation does help quite a lot to alleviate the problem of over educationDistrict infrastructure... districts are expensive, infrastructure is expensive, and the benefits of infrastructure except for roads is so minor you can safely ignore building any.  Service buildings give so much more effect per cost.Edicts generally have a fixed cost, so for a large city they can give huge boosts for almost no cost.  Somehow you can end up helping the poor for 10k a month with 10k poor in your city and they all end up with +20 cash to spend in your shops generating money from thin air.Tax those people!  Taxing people doesn't seem to hurt them much at all, just keep raising the rates.  Not being able to afford basic goods isn't a problem as long as you can visit that nice library.  Businesses seem to react properly to taxes, but people really don't seem to care too much.  They also don't seem to mind being unemployed either.Mixed:The game is hard, I love that, but I'm sure many people don't.  Part of the difficulty is the poor UI, which is bad, but the balance of a lot of things makes it fairly difficult until you figure out how to exploit the things that aren't quite balanced right.  That said, the game really could use difficulty options.  There is a fairly organic difficulty based on how fast you try to grow/advance your city and going for the different win conditions, but the lack of any kind of difficulty setting is kind of strange.After all that negative why am I recommending this game still?  I think it has potential.  It reminds me of older simulation games that are deep, complex, and challenging.  I feel like a bit of balance, polish, and tooltips could really improve the game.  I had a lot of fun playing it despite its flaws.  I'm one of those weird people who end up not liking a game with 99% positive reviews and likes a lot of games with mixed reviews.

content:
Posted: January 20
Product received for free
												In the campaign mode, you’ll lead a mayoral family from 1820 until (hopefully) 2020. Although the general mechanics play out the same each time, a large variety of events make each game slightly different. The main difference between Urban Empire and more traditional city builders is that most everything is put to a vote, so politics and relationships with parties matter. Districts are placed with zoning layouts, services, and infrastructure support. The city council must approve new districts through a vote; they also will vote on tax rate changes, modifications to existing districts, edicts, and service funding levels. Goodwill can be spent persuading parties to vote your way. A research tree contains inventions that unlock new services and edicts. Citizens have needs in several areas (such as social life, environment, health, and fun) that can be fulfilled by placing services. Urban Empire is a challenging game: it is difficult to consistently turn a monthly profit and still satisfy the needs of the citizens, and getting votes passed requires balance and skill. With an injection of meaningful political considerations, Urban Empire stands out as a city management game.


YouTube™ Video: Urban Empire Gameplay Review 

			Views: 907		

			I'm playing Urban Empire, a city management and political strategy game by Reborn Interactive and Kalypso Media. In the campaign mode, you’ll lead a mayoral family from 1820 until (hopefully) 2020.

content:
Posted: January 28
												This game is refreshingly new, and deep. At the beginning of the game you are the emperors nominee, meaning that you easily can force your will through the council. But as time passes, the more complex political landscape gets to you. Do you cling to your personal values, at the risk of alienating the powerful Christian Democratic party? What if you use all your political powers to stop the 10-hour workday, to protect your income, you risk beeing left helpless at the mayoral elections, and being voted out of office.I see people compare it to Civilization and Democracy III. It is clearly way better than Democracy III, but it is to different from Civilization to make the comparison. Further, if you think that this is the vanilla version(and it is awesome!), things are only going to get better! (remember the launch of Sim-City anyone?)

content:
Posted: January 20
												Edit: The original review was written under the assumption that a lot of the minor bugs would be fixed in the weeks after launch. However, the game seems to be published with a fire and forget attitude. Therefore i can't reccomend it anymore. ------------------------------Urban Empire is not a city building game. In Urban Empire your main goal will be to stay in control. If you want to place something as trivial as a police station, you have to be able to pay for it, pay the service costs, have your political allies and enemies approve it during a vote and be sure that the running costs don't kill your city long time. Personally, i didn't have any technical issues but there's some reports in the Forums you might wanna check out. The overall gameplay is fine but feels lacking in some aspects and now and then it's not exactly clear how some things play together until you've done some trial and error. However, overall it still makes for a good and unique game. If you're looking for a relaxing city builder, there are better options available. If you're looking for something you have to work into but is quite rewarding this might be for you. It's certainly not for everyone - but that's what steam refunds are for.

content:
Posted: January 21
												UPDATE: Having beat the game, I wouldn't recommend it at any price. The novelty wears off towards the second half of the game (only a few hours in, it's a short game) and it just becomes boring. Somehow it becomes even easier, but more tedious. Not to mention the complete lack of an epilogue (you get a pop up that says you win and asks if you want to continue playing or exit to the main menu.)Interesting game with a mix of city building and political simulation, though both are very simplified. The game is incredibly easy, I'm not sure that it's possible to lose. If you lose your re-election, you can always override the decision (it's treated like a council vote) for a few prestige points, which you are undoubtedly overflowing with. I would recommend picking this up during a Steam sale. $40 is too much for this game, but for $20 it would be a good deal.

Posted: January 23
												This is a pretty fun and different. However, the AI parties are pretty terrible. When I'm facing budgetary deficits in the last era they reject the infrastructure measures that are actually designed to save money on infrastructure spending (Like converting transport to automated) in each district. Why would the parties vote against something that would cost-costs at no expense to the people in the district?! As a result I just ended up going into debt pretty quickly with no way of reducing costs, despite the economic boost from all the business edicts and edicts that help citizen income on private companies.Also, it would be better if there was a  to when newer upgrades and ordinances are available, as it can be cumbersome and tiresome to keep checking which update.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 21
												One of the political parties that didn't like me much said that I was cheating on my wife. I countered that they were having orgies! Where else can you give a response like that in a game. Oh and my long lost pal, Peniltimo sent me a llama! Acting as mayor; you are at the whim of the city council. This is a different take if you think about Cities XL, Cities: Skylines, and Sim City as you are more concerned with governmental mayoral things rather than creating a city. I like this game but it won't keep me in it much. For those that are old enough to remember the choose your own adventure books (I;m carbon dating myself), at one point it's exciting but then the next you start feeling bored and wishing you can call early elections and send the City Council packing. The council doesnt like when I rezone and at times create another district. The zoning tool is a little bit of a mess. It tells you your zone is too small and/or illegal angle thinking you want to save money and not build a huge zone; nope. It has to be really big and of course suck your avalable money rather quickly.My system meets the minimum requirements but not the recommened requirements yet everything is pretty smooth on very high settings. If I could give a maybe vote; I'm torn in between. I would definately watch how this game evolves. For those where money is tight; I would wait for this to go on sale. For those looking for a different take as a city mayor; it's not bad but gets boring and repetive quickly. Starting a new game just gives you the same "scenarios.". Still playing so I will edit as I move along. Right now the City Council can't stand me. I threatened all of them and I;m digging dirt on one group. I blocked their vote so ha! I told them I would oppose their next vote that they brought fourth, I showed them lol. They weren;t impressed.

content:
Posted: January 20
  TL;DR  I'm not very happy with the game in its current state.It's lacking a real challenge, and the political parties feel like regular obstacles to make it harder. For me, it also lacks more options for "perfectionists" like me to "micro-manage" the city to the final and last detail, like for example managing the road grids, instead of just three options for it. The price I also feel is too much for what it is now. If updates bring more, I'll maybe buy it again and see if it makes a difference.I really don't know what to say about this game.... A part of me likes it, and a part of me doesn't.The main reason is because this game was much more "lean back" than I expected, it automatically builds road grids, and automatically decides where and how much to put industrial, residential etc. I expected a much more Cities: Skylines type of thing, with political implementations. Instead what I got, was a boring "don't worry about this we'll do it for you!" type of game. No challenge at all, hardly anything to do, and things become repetitive quickly. I also noticed the graphics of the buildings degrade a lot when you're not zoomed in on them, they literally become white squares with black windows (played on ultra).I'll list some of my Pro's and Con's. Pro's - Game was fun and intriguing for the first hour.- Feels and  is  different from other city management/builders.- The soundtrack is amazing. Con's - Graphics could be better.- Price tag is drunk, even the 35€ pre-order price I paid for it.- Game becomes dull quickly.- The AI is as dumb as me.- The UI is confusing, and the "benefits" from doing things are poorly explained. 5% Sales demand = ?. Conclusion I wish Steam had an option that was in between "Yes" or  "NO" .If you like really easy city management/builders with close to no manual control over the layout with political implementations, this might be for you. If you're willing to pay 45€.I think a more fitting price would be around 15 - 20€.For now, I'm going to give this a no. I'll probably try to get a refund.If updates supposedly improve upon the game, I'll maybe buy it again and try it out.But again, for now, I'm not happy with the game in it's current state.  Should you buy it? Maybe, I think a price reduction would make it worth it. The game is still getting updated, so hopefully they'll add something to make it better.  4,5/10

content:
Posted: January 22
												I'm updated this review to not recommended. Why? The game basically suffers from bugs, lack of certain indicators regarding the economics to understand why something is happening and a major lag near the last era's. All this take a lot of fun out of what would be a rather nice game overall. It seems the developer is not commited to making a lot of updates to address the issues since after plenty of time, none of them were fixed. Also the team doesn't make the community really feel it will address those / is commited to the game, so recommending it is a far stretch. My advice would be cheap buy / stay away - until it's properly fixed.  ---I like this game. It's an interesting new way of dealing with cities and politics. It's in no way a city builder since most of the time you can't build the city you want ( adding to both appeal and frustration of the game - but that's politics ). There are many ways to get way you want though and trying to mayor through the era's it's quit interesting to see how it all develops. There seem to be enough replayability trying different strategies ( high taxes vs low taxes, high level of services vs laissez-faire etc ) . The main problems are connected with a lack of explanation ( why is a district developing or not is hardly explained ) and not always clear what the choices are the game is trying you to have.  Also hopefully the dev's will look a little at the performance which drops in the later game. Tl;dr - Good game, needs a few updates to become really good.
